search_result.text:
DailyChatter

Editor's note: The following content is by DailyChatter. Sign up to receive the daily newsletter here.

Something for Nothing

A utopian cure proposed for the ills of the world suffered total defeat on Sunday when Swiss voters rejected giving themselves free money.

It‚Äôs a development that might hold a lesson or two for American politicians in this election season.

Put before voters in a countrywide referendum, the Swiss proposal ‚Äì called the ‚Äòbasic income‚Äô‚Äìwould have given everyone a monthly stipend of around $2,500 per month, plus extra payments per child.

People didn‚Äôt have to work to receive the money. They just had to be Swiss or a legal resident of Switzerland for five years.

Criticism of the proposal focused on common sense, some said. The basic income was a handout that would encourage laziness, harm the economy ‚Äî inflation, anyone? ‚Äî and invite freeloaders to Switzerland, they argued.

But the measure‚Äôs proponents righteously brushed aside those misgivings.

The advocates unveiled an enormous poster in the run-up to the vote that read ‚ÄúWhat would you do if your income was secure?‚Äù The implication was that folks might learn Chinese, grow exotic flowers or take up ballroom dancing rather than go to their soul-stifling office jobs.

They also marched through Zurich dressed up like robots and handing out free money, suggesting that technology would make up for the loss in productivity that might result if the state took away people's incentives to work.

Lastly, they argued that work that‚Äôs essential often generates no money ‚Äì a travesty of social justice.

"In Switzerland over 50 percent of total work that is done is unpaid,‚Äù Che Wagner from the campaign group Basic Income Switzerland, told the BBC. ‚ÄúIt's care work, it's at home, it's in different communities, so that work would be more valued with a basic income."

One could argue that only a fool would look askance at the proposal. Free money? Why not?

But the referendum failed by a wide margin. Around 77% of voters rejected the proposal. Around 23 percent voted in favor.

The Swiss opted against utopia, in other words.



Today American presidential candidates are similarly making big promises that arguably contravene reality in hopes of setting the world aright: free tuition at public universities that are already starved of public funding; trade deals that will turn around manufacturing that‚Äôs been declining for years; establishment experience that will avoid the missteps of establishments past.

To many in Switzerland and beyond, a basic income sounded too good to be true. After the Swiss cast their ballots, it was.

American politicians should watch out. Skeptics vote.

WANT TO KNOW

The Father's Shadow

It's still too close to call but Peru's ex-finance minister Pedro Pablo Kuczynski is edging out opponent Keiko Fujimori in Peru's presidential elections, according to the latest results.

With nearly 80% of ballots counted, Kuczynski has taken in 50.8% of votes, giving the Wall Street veteran a slight lead over Fujimori, who has 49.2%.

Kuczynski based his campaign on promises that he would apply his financial sector experience to improve Peru's economy and spur investment ‚Äì but he also enjoys support from many who worry that Fujimori would follow in the footsteps of her father, former president Alberto Fujimori.

The elder Fujimori is currently imprisoned for corruption and for authorizing "death squads" during his time in office in the 1990s.

No Tipples Allowed

The U.S. Navy has imposed a drinking ban and restricted off-base liberty for its 18,600 sailors stationed in Japan in an attempt to improve relations between locals and US forces.

The measures will be kept in place until "all personnel understands the impact of responsible behavior on the U.S.-Japan alliance," said the Navy.

The restrictions follow a series of incidents involving U.S. sailors in Okinawa: Police recently arrested one sailor on suspicions of drunk driving in a car accident that injured two people.

And last month, a US civilian working for the military was arrested on suspicions of dumping the body of a 20-year-old Japanese woman.

That incident sparked outrage among the residents of Okinawa, who want US forces off their island. The tensions also threaten plans to relocate a US air base to less populated parts of Okinawa.

Rare Gems, More Violence

Lapis lazuli: It's a rare, brilliant blue stone that was once prized by Egyptian pharaohs.

And now anti-corruption groups are warning that it is fueling the rise of the Taliban in a once peaceful corner of Afghanistan as tribal strongmen battle over control of Badakshan's many lapis mines.

The remote province on the border of Tajikistan has seen security deteriorate in recent years ‚Äì conflicts over the mines have weakened the area's normally anti-Taliban leaders and have created a void for the Taliban to operate and recruit.

Badakshan has seen the number of insurgent attacks rise in recent years: The district where the mines are located was seized by a militia in 2014, plunging the area into crisis.

That's not the only region seeing a surge of attacks. This weekend, Taliban gunman stormed a court in eastern Afghanistan, killing seven people, including a newly appointed court prosecutor.

DISCOVERIES

Made for Speed

The universe could be expanding faster than scientists previously thought, reported New Scientist.

According to findings due to be published in the Astrophysical Journal, researchers at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, Maryland believe the Milky Way and other galaxies are flying away from each other at a rate of around 9 percent faster than previous measurements calculated.

The concepts at play are pretty mind blowing. In fact, they are so mind blowing that scientists at least for now appear to be focusing more on how they have measured these speeds rather than the implications of the universe moving more quickly than people realized.

Scientists used to measure the speed of the expanding universe by looking at microwaves dating from the Big Bang 13.7 billion years ago. The more recent research uses the light from stars and supernovae to measure how fast things are moving.

It‚Äôs still not clear which measuring system is better.

But if the new research is right, it could mean that dark energy ‚Äì a force that counters gravity ‚Äì could rip the universe apart in around 2.8 billion years. It could also call into question Einstein‚Äôs theory of relatively. Or it could mean the scientists are missing something entirely and need to look harder at where the universe is going.

Sign up for CNN‚Äôs Wonder Theory science newsletter. Explore the universe with news on fascinating discoveries, scientific advancements and more.

CNN ‚Äî

A new telescope image showcases two entangled galaxies that will eventually merge into one millions of years from now ‚Äì and previews the eventual, similar fate of our own Milky Way galaxy.

The Gemini North telescope, located on the summit of Maunakea in Hawaii, spotted the interacting spiral galaxies about 60 million light-years away in the Virgo constellation.

The galactic pair NGC 4567 and NGC 4568, also known as the Butterfly galaxies, have just begun to collide as gravity pulls them together.

In 500 million years, the two cosmic systems will complete their merger to form a single elliptical galaxy.

At this early stage, the two galactic centers are currently 20,000 light-years apart and each galaxy has maintained its pinwheel shape. As the galaxies become more entangled, gravitational forces will lead to multiple events of intense star formation. The original structures of the galaxies will change and distort.

Over time, they will dance around each other in circles that become smaller and smaller. This tightly looped dance will pull and stretch out long streams of gas and stars, mixing the two galaxies together into something that resembles a sphere.

As millions of years pass, this galactic entanglement will consume or disperse the gas and dust needed to trigger star birth, causing stellar formation to slow and eventually cease.

Observations of other galactic collisions and computer modeling have provided astronomers with more evidence that mergers of spiral galaxies create elliptical galaxies.

Once the pair come together, the resulting formation may look more like elliptical galaxy Messier 89, also located in the Virgo constellation. Once Messier 89 lost most of the gas necessary to form stars, very little star birth occurred. Now, the galaxy is home to older stars and ancient clusters.

The afterglow of a supernova, first detected in 2020, is also visible in the new image as a bright spot in one of galaxy NGC 4568‚Äôs spiral arms.

Milky Way merger

A similar galactic merger will unfold when the Milky Way galaxy eventually collides with the Andromeda galaxy, our largest and nearest galactic neighbor. Astronomers at NASA used Hubble data in 2012 to predict when a head-on collision between the two spiral galaxies might occur. Estimates project that the event will happen in about 4 billion to 5 billion years.

Right now, a massive halo that surrounds the Andromeda galaxy is actually bumping up against the Milky Way galaxy‚Äôs halo, according to research based on Hubble Space Telescope data that published in 2020.

Andromeda‚Äôs halo, a large envelope of gas, extends out 1.3 million light-years from the galaxy, almost halfway to the Milky Way, and as much as 2 million light-years in other directions.

This neighbor, which likely contains as many as 1 trillion stars, is similar in size to our large galaxy, and it‚Äôs only 2.5 million light-years away. That may sound incredibly distant, but on an astronomical scale, that makes Andromeda so close that it‚Äôs visible in our autumn sky. You can see it as a fuzzy cigar-shaped bit of light, high in the sky during the fall.

And if we could see Andromeda‚Äôs massive halo, which is invisible to the naked eye, it would be three times the width of the Big Dipper constellation, which dwarfs anything else in our sky.

Scientists at NASA said it‚Äôs unlikely that our solar system will be destroyed when the Milky Way and Andromeda merge, but the sun might get kicked into a new region of the galaxy ‚Äì and Earth‚Äôs night sky may have some new spectacular views.

For the first time, astronomers have captured an image of the supermassive black hole at the center of our galaxy.

It‚Äôs the first direct observation confirming the presence of the black hole, known as Sagittarius A*, as the beating heart of the Milky Way.

Black holes don‚Äôt emit light, but the image shows the shadow of the black hole surrounded by a bright ring, which is light bent by the gravity of the black hole. Astronomers said the black hole is 4 million times more massive than our sun.

‚ÄúWith the (Event Horizon Telescope or EHT) image, we have zoomed in a thousand times closer than these orbits, where the gravity grows a million times stronger. At this close range, the black hole accelerates matter to close to the speed of light and bends the paths of photons in the warped (space-time).‚Äù

The black hole is about 27,000 light-years away from Earth. Our solar system is located in one of the spiral arms of the Milky Way galaxy, which is why we‚Äôre so distant from the galactic center. ‚ÄúWe were stunned by how well the size of the ring agreed with predictions from Einstein‚Äôs Theory of General Relativity,‚Äù said EHT project scientist Geoffrey Bower from the Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica, Taipei, in a statement.

‚ÄúThese unprecedented observations have greatly improved our understanding of what happens at the very (center) of our galaxy, and offer new insights on how these giant black holes interact with their surroundings.‚Äù

The results of this groundbreaking discovery were published Thursday in a special issue of The Astrophysical Journal Letters.

Searching for the black hole

It has taken five years for astronomers to capture and confirm this image and discovery. Previously, scientists observed stars orbiting some invisible, massive object at the galactic center.

The 2020 Nobel Prize in physics was awarded to scientists Roger Penrose, Reinhard Genzel and Andrea Ghez for their discoveries about black holes, including evidence shared by Ghez and Genzel about the mass of the object at the center of the Milky Way.

‚ÄúWe now see that the black hole is swallowing the nearby gas and light, pulling them into a bottomless pit,‚Äù Ramesh Narayan, a theoretical astrophysicist at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian, said in a statement. ‚ÄúThis image confirms decades of theoretical work to understand how black holes eat.‚Äù

The discovery was made possible by more than 300 researchers from 80 institutions working with a network of eight different radio telescopes around the globe that make up the Event Horizon Telescope.

The telescope is named after the ‚Äúevent horizon,‚Äù the point at which no light can escape from a black hole. This global telescope network essentially forms a single ‚ÄúEarth-size‚Äù virtual telescope when all eight are linked and observing in tandem.

It‚Äôs the second image ever captured of a black hole, with the first being the EHT‚Äôs achievement of imaging M87* at the heart of the distant Messier 87 galaxy, located 55 million light-years away, in 2019.

These panels show the first two black hole images. On the left is M87*, and the right is Sagittarius A*. European Southern Observatory/EHT Collaboration

While the two images look similar, Sagittarius A* is more than 1,000 times smaller than M87*.

‚ÄúWe have two completely different types of galaxies and two very different black hole masses, but close to the edge of these black holes they look amazingly similar,‚Äù said Sera Markoff, cochair of the EHT Science Council and a professor of theoretical astrophysics at the University of Amsterdam, in a statement.

‚ÄúThis tells us that (Einstein‚Äôs theory of) General Relativity governs these objects up close, and any differences we see further away must be due to differences in the material that surrounds the black holes.‚Äù

Capturing an impossible image

Although the Milky Way‚Äôs black hole is closer to Earth, it was much harder to image.

‚ÄúThe gas in the vicinity of the black holes moves at the same speed ‚Äì nearly as fast as light ‚Äì around both Sgr A* and M87*,‚Äù EHT scientist Chi-kwan Chan at the Steward Observatory and Department of Astronomy and the Data Science Institute of the University of Arizona, said in a statement.

‚ÄúBut where gas takes days to weeks to orbit the larger M87*, in the much smaller Sgr A* it completes an orbit in mere minutes. This means the brightness and pattern of the gas around Sgr A* was changing rapidly as the EHT Collaboration was observing it ‚Äì a bit like trying to take a clear picture of a puppy quickly chasing its tail.‚Äù

If the supermassive black holes M87* and Sagittarius A* were next to each other, Sagittarius A* would be dwarfed by M87*, which is over 1,000 times more massive. National Science Foundation/Keyi "Onyx" Li

The global network of astronomers had to develop new tools to allow for the quick movement of gas around Sagittarius A*. The resulting image is an average of different ones taken by the team. Taking the Sagittarius A* image was like capturing a photo of a grain of salt in New York City using a camera in Los Angeles, according to California Institute of Technology researchers.

‚ÄúThis image from the Event Horizon Telescope required more than just snapping a picture from telescopes on high mountaintops. It is the product of both technically challenging telescope observations and innovative computational algorithms,‚Äù Katherine Bouman, Rosenberg scholar and assistant professor of computing and mathematical sciences, electrical engineering and astronomy at the Caltech, said during a press conference.

Bouman also worked on capturing the M87* image shared in 2019. Despite the fact that the Sagittarius A* image may seem blurry, ‚Äúit‚Äôs one of the sharpest images ever made,‚Äù Bouman said.

Each telescope was pushed to its limit, which is called a diffraction limit, or the maximum fine features that it can see.

‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs basically the level that we‚Äôre seeing here,‚Äù Johnson said at the press conference. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fuzzy because to make a sharper image, we need to move our telescopes further apart or go into higher frequencies.‚Äù

On the horizon

Having images of two very different black holes will allow astronomers to determine their similarities and differences and better understand how gas behaves around supermassive black holes, which could contribute to the formation and evolution of galaxies. It is believed that black holes exist at the center of most galaxies, acting like an engine that powers them.

Sagittarius A* is at the center of our own galaxy, while M87* resides more than 55 million light-years from Earth. National Science Foundation/Keyi "Onyx" Li

Meanwhile, the EHT team is working to expand the telescope network and conduct upgrades that could lead to even more stunning images, and even movies, of black holes in the future.

Capturing a black hole in motion can show how it changes over time and what the gas does as it swirls around a black hole. Bouman and EHT member Antonio Fuentes, who will join Caltech as a postdoctoral researcher in October, are developing methods that will allow them to stitch images of the black hole together to reflect this motion.

This ‚Äúfirst direct image of the gentle giant in the center of our galaxy‚Äù is just the beginning, said Feryal √ñzel, member of the EHT Science Council and a professor of astronomy and physics and associate dean for research at the University of Arizona, during the press conference.

‚ÄúThis image is a testament to what we can accomplish, when as a global research community, we bring our brightest minds together to make the seemingly impossible, possible,‚Äù National Science Foundation Director Sethuraman Panchanathan said in a statement. ‚ÄúLanguage, continents and even the galaxy can‚Äôt stand in the way of what humanity can accomplish when we come together for the greater good of all.‚Äù

Given the week they‚Äôd had ‚Äì losing a nail-biting Carabao Cup final to Liverpool, then finding out their club was up for sale ‚Äì it was no surprise Chelsea began their match at Burnley last Saturday as if ‚Äúwondering what was the point‚Äù, said Jonathan Liew in The Observer.

The manager, Thomas Tuchel, was visibly displeased. This was not ‚Äúthe moment to do this‚Äù, he said.

Abramovich reportedly tried to sell the club for an asking price of ¬£3bn, said Duncan Castles in The Sunday Times. It seems an astronomically high sum, given that Chelsea is a club with ‚Äúinferior revenue streams‚Äù to Manchester United, which is thought to be worth about ¬£1.5bn.

Russian-born billionaire Abramovich is one of seven more oligarchs who have had sanctions placed on them in response to Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine, Sky News reported. A government document said Abramovich has had a ‚Äúclose relationship for decades‚Äù with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

How will sanctions impact Chelsea and a potential sale?

As a result of the sanctions, the club‚Äôs income has been frozen. It is under an effective transfer embargo and it cannot even sell tickets to matches.

The future of the reigning European champions is ‚Äúuncertain‚Äù, the BBC said. But a special licence allows the Stamford Bridge club to keep operating. It‚Äôs not just Candy who is interested in buying Chelsea, The Daily Telegraph reported. New York-based merchant bank Raine, which is handling the sale, has received around 150 inquiries from individuals or groups claiming to be interested. (Image credit: Jamie McDonald/Getty Images)

Following Thursday‚Äôs developments, Chelsea could ‚Äúlose millions‚Äù in sponsorship revenue, the Mail said. A Three spokesperson said it had asked Chelsea to ‚Äútemporarily suspend our sponsorship of the club, including the removal of our brand from shirts and around the stadium until further notice‚Äù.

The ‚Äúoff-field chaos‚Äù continued on Friday with ‚Äúfurther news of unrest‚Äù, The Independent reported. Kit supplier Nike may also follow main sponsor Three in suspending its deal with the club. This may be ‚Äúthe crumbling of the Roman Empire‚Äù, but someone forgot to tell Chelsea manager Tuchel, James Robson said in the Evening Standard. Amid the ‚Äúchaos, trauma and uncertainty‚Äù, the German is the man ‚Äúholding it together in the eye of the storm‚Äù. Tuchel has emerged as the figurehead of a club that is in ‚Äúdesperate need of leadership‚Äù.

Roman Abramovich has been Chelsea owner since 2003 (Image credit: Ben Stansall/AFP/Getty Images)

The glory years at Stamford Bridge

Since Abramovich bought Chelsea in 2003, they have won ‚Äúevery trophy available‚Äù, Planet Football said. Before his ownership, the Blues had won ‚Äújust one top-flight title and five domestic cups in the 98 years before his arrival‚Äù.

The Blues have lifted 18 major trophies in the 19 years since the Russian arrived at Stamford Bridge. And last month the reigning Champions League holders completed the set by beating Palmeiras 2-1 in the Fifa Club World Cup final. They did, however, miss out on a domestic trophy after losing on penalties to Liverpool in the League Cup final at Wembley.

Chelsea‚Äôs trophies under Abramovich leave their English rivals behind, The Independent said. Under ‚ÄúRoman‚Äôs empire‚Äù, the trophy cabinet at the Bridge includes: five Premier League titles, five FA Cups, three League Cups, two Champions League titles, two Europa Leagues, two Community Shields, one Uefa Super Cup and now the Club World Cup.

How Abramovich made his money

Worth an estimated $12.3bn, according to Forbes‚Äôs real-time data, Abramovich‚Äôs interests include stakes in the steel giant Evraz and the Russian mining and smelting company Norilsk Nickel.

Abramovich‚Äôs story involves a ‚Äúremarkable rise‚Äù, the Daily Mail said. Born a ‚Äúpenniless orphan‚Äù in Saratov, south-west Russia, he was brought up by his grandparents from the age of four. He first started out in business ‚Äúflogging plastic dolls on a market stall‚Äù after dropping out of college.

The majority of his fortune is ‚Äúderived from proceeds collected selling previously Russian state-owned assets he acquired following the fall of the Soviet Union‚Äù, Bloomberg said. In 2005, he sold a 73% stake in Russian oil firm Sibneft to state-owned Gazprom for $13bn, Forbes reported. Once Russia‚Äôs richest man, Abramovich‚Äôs net worth peaked at $23.5bn in 2008.

After his British investor visa expired in April 2018, Abramovich, who is Jewish, was granted Israeli citizenship. Last year he also gained EU citizenship via a Portuguese passport. He qualified under Portugal‚Äôs naturalisation scheme for descendants of Sephardic Jews, The Guardian reported.

search_result.title: USMNT coaching candidates after Gregg Berhalter fired
search_result.text:
The United States men's national team's early exit from the 2024 Copa AmeÃÅrica proved to be the final straw for head coach Gregg Berhalter's (second) tenure as the team's manager. The 50-year-old is out as head coach, as announced by the U.S. Soccer Federation on Wednesday.

Berhalter's exit, as first reported by FOX Sports' Doug McIntyre, comes after USMNT's disappointing show at this year's tournament. They tallied just three points in the group stage and failed to move on to the quarterfinals. The search for a new head coach ahead of the 2026 World Cup ‚Äì which the U.S. will jointly host with Canada and Mexico ‚Äì will begin immediately.

The New Jersey native took over as the national team's head coach in 2018, after Bruce Arena resigned from the position after a brief second stint. Berhalter went on to lead the team to a CONCACAF Nations League win in 2019-20, a CONCACAF Gold Cup win in 2021 and a 2022 World Cup run to the round of 16. U.S. Soccer initially chose not to renew his contract after 2022, though it re-hired Berhalter the following June.

After giving Berhalter five years in total at the helm, U.S. Soccer has ultimately decided to move in a different direction. All we can do for right now is speculate, but here are three candidates we think the federation could consider for the newly open USMNT head coach job.

USMNT coaching candidates

1. Steve Cherundolo

Note: A previous version of this story included B.J. Callaghan as a promising potential hire instead of Cherundolo. This story has been updated to reflect Callaghan's departure from the USMNT staff to take over as the head coach of MLS's Nashville SC.

Cherundolo is a top candidate U.S. Soccer could look to if they hope to stay with a coach who is already within the U.S. Soccer Federation umbrella.

The California native and former player for the USMNT took over as the Los Angeles FC head coach in 2022 after stops at a German U15 and U17 team, an assistant job at VfB Stuttgart and the USL. He found immediate success with Los Angeles.

In his first season, he broke an MLS record for most wins by a first-year head coach when he led LAFC to its Supporters' Shield-clinching 21st win. The record was originally set by one-time USMNT head coach (and his LAFC predecessor) Bob Bradley with the 1998 Chicago Fire.

Los Angeles went on to win the MLS Cup in Cherundolo's first year and finished as runners-up in 2023. The team is currently tied for the lead in the league's Western Conference with 43 points and has a game (or two) in hand over the other top teams.

Cherundolo is a former member of the United States men's national team, an inductee to the National Soccer Hall of Fame and a successful MLS coach. He should be among the top candidates that U.S. Soccer considers to replace his former teammate as the USMNT head coach.

2. Jim Curtin

If U.S. Soccer wants an "in-house" option that isn't Cherundolo, Curtin is one of its other best options. He has been the head coach of the Philadelphia Union (of the USSF-sanctioned MLS) since 2014 and has established himself as one of the league's best coaches.

Curtin led the Union to three U.S. Open Cup finals (2014, 2015, 2018) and the MLS Cup final in 2022. He earned MLS Coach of the Year honors in 2020 and 2022, and has a 164-106-126 record with a +114 goal differential as the Union's head coach over his decade-long tenure.

U.S. Soccer has a history of hiring successful MLS coaches as the head coach of the national team. The federation did it with Berhalter ‚Äì formerly of the Columbus Crew ‚Äì in 2018 and with Arena ‚Äì once the head coach of D.C. United ‚Äì in 1998. Curtin has one of the best track records of MLS head coaches right now and would fit the mold established by previous hiring practices.

3. HerveÃÅ Renard

Renard, a 55-year-old Frenchman and the head coach of France's national women's team, has something of a reputation for pushing national teams to a higher level.

In 2012, Renard led Zambia to its first victory in the African Cup of Nations (AFCON), a full 38 years after the team's first tournament appearance. Three years later, he led Ivory Coast to its second-ever AFCON win and first since 1992, becoming the first head coach to win an AFCON tournament with two different countries. In 2018, Renard got Morocco into the 2018 World Cup for their first time qualifying since 1998.

Two years ago, it was Renard who coached Saudi Arabia to a 2-1 World Cup-opening win over eventual champions Argentina.

Attempts to draw Renard to the United States will be more difficult than either of the other candidates. In January of this year, Ivory Coast attempted to bring him back "on loan" from the French women's national team for this year's AFCON tournament, but the French Football Federation rejected their request.

Honorable mention: JuÃàrgen Klopp

JuÃàrgen Klopp is never going to be the head coach of the United States men's national team, but it is a fun dream to have. An all-time great manager coming to coach up the American team after stepping down from his decade-long job at Liverpool? Of course that's an exciting concept.

Klopp himself once likened his teams' style of play to heavy metal in that they are highly aggressive, with an inclination to immediately press opposing teams after losing possession. Using his tactics, Klopp's Liverpool teams over the last 10 years have been among the Premier League's most successful, winning the league in 2019-20, the FA Cup in 2021-22 and the EFL (formerly Carabao Cup) in 2021-22 and this year.

The German coaching mastermind is one of the best coaches in the world. Given his price point and recently stated desire to take a break from managing soccer teams, he's nothing but a pipe dream for USMNT fans.

search_result.text:
CNN ‚Äî

The German phrase ‚ÄòLuftschl√∂sser bauen‚Äô literally translates as ‚Äòbuilding castles in the air,‚Äô a whimsical image indicative of the idiom‚Äôs meaning ‚Äì daydreaming about pipedreams.

This season, ‚ÄòLuftschl√∂sser bauen‚Äô is an idea that might resonate with many Liverpool fans.

Back in January, Liverpool was a seemingly insurmountable 14 points behind Manchester City in the Premier League; had dispatched Shrewsbury Town in the fourth round of the FA Cup; was preparing for its round of 16 clash against Inter Milan in the Champions League; and had just drawn 0-0 with Arsenal in the first leg of the Carabao Cup semifinal.

Winning all four trophies appeared to be a pipedream barely worth daydreaming about.

Subsequently the Reds have closed the gap to City in the title race and navigated every cup knockout round to keep their hopes of an unprecedented quadruple mathematically still alive, although a recent draw against Tottenham Hotspur in the Premier League dealt their title hopes a severe blow.

For Liverpool to win the Premier League, it now needs City to slip up in its last two games. That would seem unlikely given City has won its previous two games 5-0 and 5-1.

The manager constructing the foundations of this remarkable season is, of course, J√ºrgen Klopp, who recently extended his contract with Liverpool.

Before his arrival at Liverpool, the German managed Borussia Dortmund for seven seasons, guiding the club to a Bundesliga title in 2011 as well as a league and cup double in 2012. Under Klopp, Dortmund also reached a Champions League final.

Klopp's Liverpool has won the Carabao Cup, is mathematically in contention for the Premier League, and will play in the FA Cup and Champions League finals. Chris Brunskill/Fantasista/Getty Images

‚ÄúJ√ºrgen is a special person,‚Äù Dortmund‚Äôs captain Marco Reus tells CNN Senior Sport Analyst Darren Lewis. ‚ÄúI remember when I moved to Dortmund and had the first conversation with him. When he walks into the room, there‚Äôs just something in the air.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs charismatic, he‚Äôs got a lot of energy, and he‚Äôs just a good guy to just talk to privately about other things, not just football.‚Äù

Reus‚Äô association with Klopp stretches back to 2012, when Klopp ‚Äì then Dortmund coach ‚Äì persuaded him to return to the club where he had been a youth player.

In his first season under Klopp following his move from Borussia M√∂nchengladbach, Reus contributed 19 goals and 16 assists in 49 appearances as Dortmund reached the Champions League final where it lost 2-1 to rivals Bayern Munich.

Reus has become a talismanic figure for Dortmund. Alex Gottschalk/vi/DeFodi Images/Getty Images

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs definitely one of the best coaches in the world because otherwise you don‚Äôt stay at the top for so long,‚Äù Reus says. ‚ÄúI hope for him that he manages to do it (quadruple) this year and I wouldn‚Äôt put it past him.‚Äù

‚ÄòEnergy he brings every day‚Äô

When Klopp arrived at Dortmund in 2008, the club had just endured its worst season in 20 years, finishing 13th in the Bundesliga.

By recruiting smartly ‚Äì players such as Robert Lewandowski and Jakub B≈Çaszczykowski were signed relatively cheaply ‚Äì and implementing his now familiar tactic of ‚Äògegenpress‚Äô ‚Äì whereby the team immediately try to win back possession after losing it ‚Äì Klopp built a title-winning side in three years.

‚ÄúBefore he came, things weren‚Äôt looking so rosy here and he took the club to another level,‚Äù Reus recalls.

‚ÄúOf course, that had a lot to do with him and the team at the time as well.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt put that into words because it‚Äôs not just one word. It‚Äôs still, I would say, this energy, willingness to suffer every day and to get the maximum out of it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd, of course, he has had a lot of experiences in the last few years when he was here and then also in the first years at Liverpool, which has helped him a lot.‚Äù

Klopp managed Dortmund for seven seasons. Lars Baron/Bongarts/Getty Images

Similarly, at Liverpool, the success now enjoyed by the team did not immediately materialize.

It took Klopp‚Äôs charges four years to win the Champions League, and another year to win the Premier League title.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs been doing a great job for years both here and in Liverpool,‚Äù says Reus. ‚ÄúHow he‚Äôs built the team, how he‚Äôs built the club, both here and in Liverpool, is immense. That energy that he brings every day, I think, you can only take your hat off to him.‚Äù

On Saturday, Liverpool play Chelsea in the FA Cup final at Wembley and then Real Madrid in the Champions League final on May 28 in Paris.

For the time being the pipedream ‚Äì the idea of ‚Äòbuilding castles in the air‚Äô ‚Äì is still attainable.

England‚Äôs Lionesses, the reigning European champions, will play in their first ever Fifa Women‚Äôs World Cup final against Spain on Sunday after defeating co-hosts Australia 3-1 in today‚Äôs semi-final clash at Stadium Australia.

It was a ‚Äúhistoric evening‚Äù in Sydney, said Emma Sanders on BBC Sport, as goals from Ella Toone, Lauren Hemp and Alessia Russo ‚Äúspoiled‚Äù the Australian ‚Äúparty‚Äù. Sarina Wiegman‚Äôs side will now be aiming to become the first senior England football team since 1966 to lift a World Cup.

Chelsea star Sam Kerr sent the vast majority of the 75,784 spectators into ‚Äúraptures‚Äù and ‚Äúsparked wild scenes of celebration‚Äù in the 63rd minute, said Tom Garry in The Telegraph. The Australia captain levelled the scores with a ‚Äúrocket from range‚Äù that ‚Äúflew past‚Äù England keeper Mary Earps. But despite Kerr‚Äôs ‚Äústunning‚Äù strike ‚Äúthe ride ends here‚Äù for the Matildas, said Vince Rugari in the Sydney Morning Herald, as their ‚Äúhistory-making, record-breaking, nation-changing‚Äù World Cup run was ‚Äústopped in its tracks by the old enemy‚Äù.

Will James come straight back in?

Spain, who beat Sweden 2-1 in a dramatic semi-final yesterday, will provide an ‚Äúeven tougher‚Äù test, said Lionesses striker Russo, who has now scored seven goals in 12 appearances at major tournaments for her country. Every single game at this World Cup ‚Äúhas been of the highest level‚Äù, so ‚Äúwe have to be ready‚Äù, she added, ‚Äúbut we‚Äôve been dreaming since we were little girls, so we‚Äôre excited‚Äù.

One ‚Äúheadache‚Äù ‚Äì a good one ‚Äì is that England will have Lauren James available for Sunday‚Äôs final after her suspension. Will she come straight back into the starting XI, asked former England and Arsenal defender Alex Scott on BBC One. Ella Toone is ‚Äúright there‚Äù and it‚Äôs a ‚Äúgreat headache‚Äù for Wiegman to have, she added. ‚ÄúI would start with the same 11‚Äù against Spain and ‚Äúhave someone like Lauren James come on‚Äù.

Wiegman has ‚Äòa golden touch‚Äô

The semi-final victory means that Wiegman has now become the ‚Äúfirst coach to guide two different countries to a Women‚Äôs World Cup final‚Äù, said AFP. She took her native Netherlands to the 2019 ‚Äúshowpiece match‚Äù, where they were defeated 2-0 by the United States. Having the chance as a coach or a player to make it to two finals is ‚Äúreally special‚Äù, Wiegman said. ‚ÄúI never take anything for granted, but it‚Äôs like I‚Äôm living in a fairytale or something.‚Äù

In ‚Äútrying to capture‚Äù just ‚Äúhow good a manager‚Äù Wiegman is, said Luke Edwards in The Telegraph, it‚Äôs hard not to make comparisons between men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs football. But make no mistake, after guiding England to their first Women‚Äôs World Cup final, just a year after leading them to glory at the Euros, Wiegman‚Äôs ‚Äúgenius‚Äù is ‚Äúnot up for debate‚Äù. Pep Guardiola is the ‚Äúoutstanding manager of his generation‚Äù in men‚Äôs football, but Wiegman is ‚Äúprobably the best of hers, too‚Äù.

search_result.title: Anti-pipeline push, Lynyrd Skynyrd: News from around our 50 states
search_result.text:
From USA TODAY Network and wire reports

Alabama

Montgomery: Gov. Kay Ivey on Friday reallocated $12.3 million of the state‚Äôs coronavirus relief funds to hire travel nurses to help hospitals overwhelmed with COVID-19 patients. The Republican governor announced the move as the state continues to see a surge in virus cases, straining hospital resources and staff. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm pleased to see more folks getting vaccinated, but we are still in the thick of COVID-19 and our hospitals are overwhelmed,‚Äù Ivey said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe money is coming from the state‚Äôs share of CARES Act funds. Until our vaccination rates rise and our COVID-19 hospitalization rates fall, we will need the extra support these nurses provide.‚Äù The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated a nurse staffing crisis, sending U.S. hospitals into a competition for travel nurses and staff to handle the crush of patients this summer. Hospitals need more staff to handle the patient loads, while some nurses have left because they are exhausted, taken lucrative travel jobs or are out sick because they themselves are sick with COVID-19. Baptist Medical Center South in Montgomery, like hospitals across the country, has turned to travel staff to fill positions. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a national arms race for clinical talent,‚Äù CEO Peter Selman, said. He said the hospital is paying up to $155 an hour to national staffing firms.

Alaska

Juneau: Residents in Wrangell and Petersburg now have the ability to text 911 for help when calling isn‚Äôt an option. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been working out excellent,‚Äù Petersburg Police Department Chief James Kerr said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs designed for the hearing impaired or domestic violence situations. If you can‚Äôt talk to the dispatch but you need help, you can text.‚Äù A third-party provider helped implement the technology with the two police departments. ‚ÄúOne of the really big benefits I see with this is for search and rescue,‚Äù Kerr said, noting Alaska‚Äôs rugged terrain can make it difficult to get a call signal. ‚ÄúBut you can send a text through. It gives us GPS coordinates and everything else.‚Äù The Juneau Police Department is also investigating a similar system, Lt. Krag Campbell said in an email to the Juneau Empire. He noted texting 911 could be useful in active shooter situations or other times when speaking into the phone would put a caller at risk, betraying their position. Currently, the option is only available to AT&T and GCI customers, Kerr said. Texters using other providers get a message that the service is not available. No one has texted police yet with it, other than kids trying to play a prank. But the text sent to emergency services also comes with the texter‚Äôs location, allowing police to arrive at the kids‚Äô location and caution them not to misuse the service.

Arizona

Tucson: The father of an elementary school student was arrested after he and two other men showed up to the campus with zip ties, threatening to make a ‚Äúcitizen‚Äôs arrest‚Äù on the principal over a coronavirus quarantine, school officials said Friday. Diane Vargo, principal of Mesquite Elementary School in Tucson, said the parent came to her office Thursday with his son in tow. The father was upset the child would have to isolate and miss a school field trip because of possible exposure to someone with COVID-19. She said two other men also ‚Äúbarged in.‚Äù One was carrying ‚Äúmilitary, large, black zip ties and standing in my doorway.‚Äù Vargo said she tried to deescalate the situation while explaining the school had to follow county health protocols. ‚ÄúI felt violated that they were in my office claiming I was breaking the law and they were going to arrest me,‚Äù a visibly shaken Vargo said in a video statement released by the Vail Unified School District. ‚ÄúTwo of the men weren‚Äôt parents at our school, so I felt threatened.‚Äù In a video posted on social media, Vargo can be heard calmly asking them to leave. One of them replies they aren‚Äôt leaving because they‚Äôre not going to let her control the situation. The principal called Tucson police. School officials said the man arrested was the father. Vargo said they are pursuing charges against the other two men.

Arkansas

Paris: The Frontier‚Äôs Day festival returns to town Oct.2. Tonya Fletcher, executive director of the Paris Area Chamber of Commerce and organizer of the festival, described Frontier‚Äôs Day as ‚Äúwhere yesterday meets today for today.‚Äù This year marks the 43rd year Paris has celebrated Frontier‚Äôs Day. Typically, the festival draws 3,000 to 4,000 people each year, but Fletcher said it is hard to say how many people the pandemic will keep at home. ‚ÄúI still think we‚Äôll have a good crowd,‚Äù she said, allowing that it will likely be a smaller gathering than in the past. Frontier‚Äôs Day will officially begin at 9 a.m. and end at 4 p.m., but Paris will celebrate its monthly ‚ÄúFirst Fridays‚Äù music night the evening prior, wrapping at 11 p.m. For the festival, the city will block off three sides of the square, only leaving Highway 22 open to traffic. Frontier‚Äôs Day has fun activities lined up for all ages, Fletcher said. Children can roam the free pumpkin patch, where they can pick out pumpkins to decorate. There will be live music, and the day will begin with a parade and end with a pageant. During opening ceremonies, area historian Curtis Varnell will discuss the legacy of the Paris Courthouse, which turned 150 this year.

California

San Francisco: The mysterious deaths of a Northern California family of hikers and their dog have led federal officials to close 28 miles along the Merced River, where high levels of toxic algae were detected. The Bureau of Land Management closed campgrounds and recreation areas along the river, between the towns of Briceburg and Bagby, on Friday after receiving test results of water samples downstream from where the family died. Algal blooms can form in waterways that are shallow and warm. ‚ÄúThese algal blooms can produce toxins that can make people and pets extremely sick,‚Äù Elizabeth Meyer-Shields, a BLM field manager, said in a statement. ‚ÄúWe will continue to monitor for the algae‚Äôs presence and look forward to when the public can safely recreate in the Merced River.‚Äù The bodies of John Gerrish, his wife, Ellen Chung, their 1-year-old daughter, Miju, and their dog were found Aug. 17 on a hiking trail close to the river in the Sierra National Forest. A family friend had reported them missing. A cause of death has not been determined, and investigators are considering whether toxic algal blooms or other hazards may have contributed to the deaths. Toxicology reports are still pending, and investigators have ruled out any weapons being used or dangerous gases from a mine along the trail.

Colorado

Denver: The state‚Äôs nonpartisan redistricting commission has proposed a congressional map that would create a new swing seat in the northern Denver suburbs and lump conservative firebrand Rep. Lauren Boebert into a Boulder-based, solidly Democratic seat currently held by liberal Rep. Joe Neguse. The proposal from the commission staff Friday would rearrange the political geography as part of the once-a-decade redistricting process. It‚Äôs the first test of the commission model approved by voters in 2018. The map will be followed by a series of hearings, along with a map of state legislative districts. Both may change significantly in the weeks to come as the commission races to meet an end-of-the-month deadline to approve maps. The congressional map keeps the four Democratic seats relatively safe, as well as preserving three as solidly Republican. It would add a new swing seat running from Adams County to Greeley that voted Democratic by 1.9 percentage points in last year‚Äôs Senate election. That could make the final breakdown of the state‚Äôs congressional districts 4-4, an underwhelming split for Democrats in a state they won by 13 points in last year‚Äôs presidential election. Still, Democrats see the map as an improvement over the initial map, which had a similar partisan division.

Connecticut

Hartford: Nursing homes will once again be allowed to hire temporary nursing aides as they deal with staffing shortages during the pandemic. Gov. Ned Lamont on Friday signed an executive order that revives the state‚Äôs nurses aides program that was used last year. Under the program, the temporary workers will be allowed to provide nursing-related services ‚Äì but nothing that requires a license. The governor‚Äôs office said the idea is to use those aides to help serve residents who do not have COVID-19, allowing permanent staff to focus on patients who have tested positive for the coronavirus. The measure also will assure adequate staffing at long-term care facilities, which have struggled with hiring and retaining workers, the governor‚Äôs office said. Connecticut recorded 111 cases of COVID-19 among nursing home patients and 94 cases among staff between Aug. 18 and Aug. 31, according to the state Department of Health. There were 16 patient deaths related to the coronavirus during that time and none among staff. The governor on Friday also extended to Sept. 27 the deadline for nursing home workers to be vaccinated against COVID-19.

Delaware

Wilmington: Numerous Walgreens pharmacies across the state have been unable to process prescriptions because of flooding from the remnants of Hurricane Ida. The internet services vendor for the stores was affected by the historic flooding Thursday, bringing delays for people receiving vital medications. Walgreens has apologized for the inconvenience. The company said it is working to address the issues that have caused the delays. ‚ÄúOur internet services vendor is currently working to fully restore their operations as a result of the storms in the Northeast, which has resulted in some technical difficulties causing longer than normal wait times in several of our stores,‚Äù a Walgreens spokesperson said in an email over the weekend. ‚ÄúI ended up at the urgent care on Friday because my throat was starting to close due to an allergic reaction I had and couldn‚Äôt get my meds in time,‚Äù one person commented on a Facebook post about the issue from the Delaware Department of Health and Social Services. ‚ÄúThis is an issue and delay of care that represent lives at risk.‚Äù

District of Columbia

Washington: A new art exhibit in the nation‚Äôs capital is remembering the twin towers, just ahead of the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks. The show opened Saturday at the National Building Museum and features more than 50 years of photos of the World Trade Center, WUSA-TV reports. The images, all captured by photographer Camilo Jose Vergara, chart the history of the iconic towers from their construction to the attack that brought them down and what came next. ‚ÄúI closely followed the construction of the towers, watching heavy trucks bring in steel or haul away dirt amid the noise of jackhammers and clanging metal,‚Äù Vergara wrote in an essay accompanying the photographs. ‚ÄúAs they rose to become the tallest buildings in the world, I regarded them as a wild expression of mistaken priorities in a troubled time. ‚ÄúEventually, my early resentment faded, and I grew to see them as great human creations. As I traveled farther away to photograph the towers from distant boroughs, they seemed to lose their solidity and become mysterious, fantastic, and alluring.‚Äù Chrysanthe Broikos, a consulting curator at the National Building Museum, said she hopes the exhibit inspires visitors to think about what the towers and those who worked there meant to the world, as well as how the world responded when they fell.

Florida

Jacksonville: The store that inspired Lynyrd Skynyrd‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Ballad of Curtis Loew‚Äù has been demolished. Jacksonville‚Äôs Woodcrest Grocery Building, where Ronnie Van Zant allegedly met ‚Äúthe finest picker to ever play the blues,‚Äù was torn down late last month. The abandoned store was a hangout for generations of kids. The song, written by Van Zant and Allen Collins, tells the story of a young boy who collected bottles to raise money so the old man who hung out at the corner store could play his dobro. Curtis Loew was fictional, but the store was real. It was known as Claude‚Äôs in the late ‚Äô50s and early ‚Äô60s and was right down the street from the house where Van Zant was raised. Scott Hill, who grew up in the neighborhood, said fans started dropping by the site last week to grab cinder blocks as souvenirs after hearing about the demolition. Gene Odom, who wrote a book about the band and leads tours of Lynyrd Skynyrd landmarks for fans, said the building has been vacant for decades. The building started collapsing during the demolition of nearby trailers and had to be taken down. A real estate group said a residential home will be built there. The band is still touring but pulled out of the Pro Football Hall of Fame concert last month after guitarist Rickey Medlocke tested positive for the coronavirus.

Georgia

Atlanta: Morehouse College announced Friday that it has canceled this year‚Äôs homecoming festivities due to a surge of COVID-19. Events were scheduled to occur Oct. 10-17 and will not be rescheduled. The Oct. 16 football game against Fort Valley State University will still be played but without the ‚Äúhomecoming‚Äù designation and with fewer tickets available to the game to implement social distancing. University officials said they made the decision last week as Georgia broke its record for COVID-19 hospitalizations. ‚ÄúThe state has the sixth-highest per capita infection rate in the nation, and an unprecedented number of young people have become ill with the virus,‚Äù Morehouse President David Thomas said. ‚ÄúGiven the circumstances, a massive in-person gathering on our campus presents a public health risk to our students which is impossible to ignore.‚Äù Thomas said nearly 100% of the students and employees on campus have met the school‚Äôs vaccination requirement. With ‚Äúaggressive‚Äù masking requirements and other safety protocols, Morehouse has limited the spread of the coronavirus on campus, he said. But he had to consider the broader community. ‚ÄúKeeping our students safe is our top priority,‚Äù he said. In place of homecoming, the school will host a students-only fall festival.

Hawaii

Honolulu: President Joe Biden‚Äôs appointment of two Native Hawaiians to the U.S. Department of the Interior could influence federal policy for the state‚Äôs Indigenous people and other Pacific Islanders. Summer Sylva, who is currently head of the Native Hawaiian Legal Corporation, was appointed last week as senior adviser for Native Hawaiian affairs. Keone Nakoa, the Washington, D.C., bureau chief for the Office of Hawaiian Affairs, has been appointed deputy assistant secretary for insular and international affairs. The positions carry a great deal of influence over federal policy involving Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders, Hawaii Public Radio reports. Sylva will report directly to Interior Secretary Deb Haaland, the first Native American to lead the agency. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs in a critical role to be in the secretary‚Äôs inner circle,‚Äù said Esther Kia‚Äôaina, a Honolulu City councilwoman who led the department‚Äôs Office of Insular Affairs under former President Barack Obama‚Äôs administration. Sylva‚Äôs appointment signals the agency‚Äôs desire to tackle Native Hawaiian issues, including homelands and self-governance, Kia‚Äôaina said. Nakoa will be serving in an office that oversees the U.S. territories of American Samoa, Guam and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.

Idaho

Boise: State officials are boosting pay and offering bonuses to try to attract and maintain correctional officers. About 24% of correctional officer positions at the Idaho Department of Correction were vacant last month, including 190 vacancies at the agency‚Äôs prisons in Kuna, south of Boise. ‚ÄúAttracting and hiring the right people to our security ranks is only one part of the equation,‚Äù Jeff Ray, the department‚Äôs public information officer, told the Idaho Press. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre putting an equal amount of emphasis on retaining the staff who have and continue to admirably serve the people of Idaho.‚Äù New correctional officers will receive $19 an hour, up from the previous $16.75. New hires will also get $1,500 bonuses and be eligible for $1,500 yearly retention bonuses during their first five years. Current employees will see hourly raises ranging from $0.75 for wardens to $2.25 for correctional officers starting Sept. 5. Also, on Oct. 15, all current correctional officers will receive a one-time retention bonus of $1,500. Correctional officers often must work mandatory 16-hour shifts because there aren‚Äôt enough workers. Department of Correction Director Josh Tewalt said the pay Idaho offers correctional workers isn‚Äôt competitive with surrounding states, such as an Oregon prison paying new correctional officers $22.64 an hour.

Illinois

Chicago: Years in the making, the visitor center and state historic site grounds at the Pullman National Monument have officially opened to the public. Chicago‚Äôs first national monument marks the site where Pullman passenger railroad cars were built. Employees lived nearby in the neighborhood on the city‚Äôs South Side. The sprawling Pullman company factory closed in 1982. The National Park Services‚Äô visitor center features exhibits on worker demonstrations that helped plant the seeds of the modern labor movement. For instance, Black railroad workers won a significant labor agreement in the 1930s that helped lead to worker protections. Robert Bushwaller, a Historic Pullman Foundation board member, said he was encouraged by the crowd Saturday. Some drove vintage cars to mark the opening day during the Labor Day weekend. ‚ÄúThe public support has been better than expected,‚Äù Bushwaller told the Chicago Sun-Times. ‚ÄúThe turnout is tremendous. They remember so much from how it used to be and want to see if it still tasted that way, and they‚Äôve been satisfied.‚Äù Former President Barack Obama designated the factory and surrounding area a national monument in 2015. Restoration and revitalization at the site has been ongoing for years.

Indiana

Indianapolis: Gov. Eric Holcomb issued seven pardons to convicted criminals during his first year in office but hasn‚Äôt granted any more pardons in the past 31/ 2 years, with officials saying the number of applications for the governor to clear criminal records has declined to a trickle, The (Fort Wayne) Journal Gazette reports. Indiana‚Äôs expansive expungement law ‚Äì first passed by the Legislature in 2013 ‚Äì has meant fewer people seeking pardons, as that process of asking a judge to clear past convictions is both simpler and more private, said Charles Miller, vice chairman of the Indiana Parole Board. ‚ÄúQuite frankly, I knew the numbers were way down, but even I was shocked by just how low they were,‚Äù Miller said. ‚ÄúSpeaking personally, pardons are the best part of my job, as you get to the good things people accomplish after what is usually just an unfortunate mistake.‚Äù The pardons Holcomb issued in 2017 were largely holdovers from when Mike Pence was governor. The most prominent case was that of Keith Cooper, whose pardon request over his conviction for a 1996 robbery in Elkhart languished under Pence even as the state parole board, the local prosecutor and witnesses supported his exoneration.

Iowa

Iowa City: The University of Iowa‚Äôs graduate student workers union is calling for stronger on-campus mitigation protocols against the coronavirus. The union members sent a list of demands to the UIowa administration and state‚Äôs Board of Regents in a letter dated Sept. 1 and followed that up Thursday morning with a ‚Äúdie-in‚Äù protest on the Pentacrest to draw attention to their plea. Kansas

Kelly said Thursday that most of the state has been in drought or abnormally dry conditions for several weeks, and she encouraged residents to do what the can to minimize the risk of fire. Kentucky

Frankfort: Tucked into the pandemic-heavy agenda for a special legislative session is a request to strengthen Kentucky‚Äôs negotiating hand in trying to reel in mega-sized economic development projects. Gov. Andy Beshear said Saturday that he will ask the GOP-led Legislature to give the state‚Äôs recruiting team more flexibility in offering incentives for investment projects topping $2 billion. ‚ÄúAs we sit here today, we have at least five potential projects that would be that size,‚Äù Beshear told reporters. ‚ÄúIn other words, the largest in our commonwealth‚Äôs history.‚Äù The Democratic governor announced Saturday that he‚Äôs calling lawmakers back to the statehouse for a special session that begins Tuesday and will be dominated by coronavirus-related issues. Louisiana

Baton Rouge: Families looking for their loved ones who evacuated from Hurricane Ida to a state shelter are getting help from the state. The Louisiana Department of Children and Family Services on Saturday launched ‚ÄúConnect,‚Äù a tool that will help families connect with each other. The number to call is 225-342-2727. Maine

Oxford: The state is continuing to try to slow the spread of the invasive emerald ash borer with new restrictions. The Maine Forest Service has issued an emergency order preventing the movement of ash trees and products from areas including Norway, Oxford and Lovell in Oxford County. The order limits the movement of ash trees for planting and ash tree products such as logs, pulpwood, lumber and firewood from areas that are considered likely to harbor the pest. Maryland

Annapolis: Nursing homes in the state are seeing another rise in coronavirus cases, leading facilities to suspend visits from loved ones. The Washington Post reports the halt to visitations has led to a new wave of despair in facilities that were struck hard by COVID-19. The impact of loneliness on the health of the elderly has been extreme. Maryland has 227 nursing homes. Gov. Larry Hogan had ordered that all nursing home employees receive at least one vaccine dose by last week. Facilities that fail to comply will be subject to fines. The percentage of employees who have received a vaccine dose is 82%. At the same time, nearly 90% of all nursing home residents have had at least one vaccine dose, and 86.1% are fully inoculated. Meanwhile, outbreaks are rising in Maryland‚Äôs nursing homes. Outbreaks are defined by the federal government as at least one COVID-19 case. In July, fewer than 10 facilities had an outbreak. But by early August, there were 33. On Friday, there were 92.

Massachusetts

Salem: What started as a project to restore the gravestones of three Black men and women who played a role in the abolitionist movement on the North Shore is evolving into a larger effort to find and restore the final resting places for other African American families, officials said. In Salem‚Äôs Howard Street Cemetery, two of the stones marking the burial sites of Venus Chew, Prince Farmer and Samuel Payne, all of whom died in the 1850s, are broken into pieces, The Salem News reports. The graves to be restored are in what Rachel Meyer, a stone conservator with Epoch Preservation, described as a corner of the cemetery, effectively segregated from the main cemetery. They occupy a square piece of land the city donated to expand the cemetery to bury African Americans. The three stones in question have fallen over in time and were sinking into the ground when an area resident contacted Meyer about fixing them. Doreen Wade, president of Salem United, said she‚Äôs enthusiastically behind the project because of what it represents ‚Äì more than just repairing fragmented gravestones, it‚Äôs repairing a fragmented story of Salem‚Äôs past.

Michigan

Flat Rock: A Ford plant is the source of benzene vapor in sewers that forced the evacuation of 10 homes and a school in the Detroit suburb of Flat Rock, according to state and company officials. The Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy confirmed Friday that the source of the flammable vapor is a fuel leak at the Ford Flat Rock Assembly Plant. ‚ÄúHAZMAT technicians will begin mitigating flammable vapors in the municipal sanitary system by injecting fire suppressant foam. The Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes and Energy said in an email late Friday that an estimated 1,000 to 3,000 gallons of unleaded gasoline spilled into the sewers.

Minnesota

Bemidji: Four congressional Democrats who are part of the progressive ‚ÄúSquad‚Äù and want President Joe Biden to stop construction of the Enbridge Line 3 oil pipeline traveled to the shores of the Mississippi River to make their plea. Reps. Ilhan Omar of Minnesota, Cori Bush of Missouri, Ayanna Pressley of Massachusetts and Rashida Tlaib of Michigan spent the holiday weekend visiting Bemidji and other parts of northern Minnesota to speak with members of Indigenous communities and others who have been protesting the project. Line 3 starts in Alberta and clips a corner of North Dakota before crossing Minnesota en route to Enbridge‚Äôs terminal in Superior, Wisconsin. The 337-mile line in Minnesota is the last step in replacing the deteriorating pipeline that was built in the 1960s. ‚ÄúWe have been encouraged by Joe Biden‚Äôs boldness so far,‚Äù Omar said, referencing his January decision to cancel a border-crossing permit for the Keystone XL pipeline that would have carried oil from Canada to Nebraska. ‚ÄúNow we have another chance to reject a moving pipeline. We hope you will act.‚Äù Minnesota Republican legislators condemned the visit, which they said ‚Äúwill only serve to incite the obstructionists,‚Äù the Star Tribune reports.

Mississippi

Money: A historical marker describing the events leading up to the killing of Emmett Till was knocked down just days after the 66th anniversary of his death. The black Mississippi Freedom Trail marker with gold writing typically stands in front of the remains of Bryant‚Äôs Grocery and Meat Market, where, in 1955, the Black 14-year-old was accused of whistling at a white woman. Missouri

Jefferson City: Republican Secretary of State Jay Ashcroft is urging the General Assembly to prohibit local election workers from helping absentee voters correct mistakes, a move that would mean some votes aren‚Äôt counted. ‚ÄúWe would like to see legislation that does not allow for curing of absentee ballots,‚Äù Deputy Secretary of State Trish Vincent told the House Elections Committee last week. ‚ÄúCuring‚Äù is a common term for fixing errors. More than 28% of Missouri voters cast ballots by mail in November, up from 8% in 2018. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think we‚Äôre going to go back to the mail-in like we did during COVID,‚Äù said Republican Rep. Dan Shaul of Imperial, chairman of the House Elections Committee.

Montana

West Glacier: Wildlife workers at Glacier National Park trapped and killed a black bear that officials said became a public safety risk after it lingered around a campground. The bear took apples from an open vehicle trunk while visitors were nearby at the Many Glacier Campground, officials said. It kept returning despite park staff attempts to scare it away. They said it could not be relocated due to safety concerns.

Nebraska

Lincoln: State education officials halted their plans Friday for new health education standards after criticism from some parents and conservative family-values groups that the content was sexually inappropriate. The State Board of Education voted 5-1 to indefinitely postpone the standards, with one member abstaining, according to the Omaha World-Herald. The standards were nonbinding recommendations, so local schools could simply have ignored them, but opponents still railed against the proposal. The new resolution the board passed says members will determine an appropriate time to address health education standards after considering the status of the pandemic and the needs of local children, schools and communities. Under board rules, any member can attempt to revive the process with support from the majority. The first draft released in March faced strong opposition, as did a second draft released in July, despite removal of many topics opponents disliked. The initial draft called for teaching children as young as first grade about gender identity and gender stereotypes and older children about homophobia, transphobia, and vaginal, oral and anal sex. Republican Gov. Pete Ricketts blasted the draft, saying it was developed with input from activists and promoted ‚Äúgender ideology.‚Äù

Nevada

The tribes say their ancestors were massacred in the late 1800s at the proposed Thacker Pass site. Du emphasized in the ruling late Friday in Reno that she has pledged to hear and rule on the merits of the case before Lithium Nevada Corp. hopes to begin construction early next year on the mine the U.S. Bureau of Land Management approved in January. She rejected a similar request in July for a preliminary injunction sought by environmentalists who claim the digging would destroy critical habitat for greater sage grouse. Du said Friday that she was ‚Äúnot unpersuaded by the tribes‚Äô broader equitable and historical arguments.‚Äù But she said that there was no evidence the bureau acted unreasonably, nor that the mine was planned on an actual massacre site, and the agency has contingency plans if ‚Äúhuman remains are unexpectedly discovered.‚Äù

New Hampshire

Sununu, 46, is fully vaccinated against COVID-19. He received the single-shot Johnson & Johnson vaccine April 10.

In the days after the destruction, the Eachus family has seen an outpouring of support and help, both physical and financial.

New Mexico

A record-setting number of homicides in Albuquerque this year is spurring concerns about violent crime and shortcomings of the police and justice system. New York

North Carolina

The defendants said they fired Billard not because he was gay but because ‚Äúhe engaged in ‚Äòadvocacy‚Äô that went against the Catholic Church‚Äôs beliefs‚Äù when he publicly announced his engagement to another man, the ruling said.

North Dakota

North Dakota Native Vote Executive Director Nicole Donaghy said subdistricts would allow ‚Äúpeople on reservations to elect candidates of their choice.‚Äù She said in the past decade there have been elections encompassing the Standing Rock Indian Reservation in which ‚Äúwe‚Äôve had several Native Americans run for county commission, run for a legislative seat for that district, and they were not able to be elected because of the dilution of the populations with the non-Native population that surrounds the reservation.‚Äù

Ohio

Oklahoma

Rhode Island

South Carolina

South Dakota

The Texas law authorizes private citizens to sue abortion providers and anyone involved in aiding an abortion, including someone who drives a woman to a clinic. Tennessee

But on Aug. 16, he signed a statewide order allowing parents to opt out of the requirement for nonmedical reasons. Hundreds of students have been attending classes without masks ever since. The parents‚Äô lawsuit claims Lee‚Äôs order violates the Americans with Disabilities Act.

Texas

The law also leaves enforcement to private citizens through lawsuits instead of to prosecutors through criminal charges. Utah
