search_result.title: Cemeteries tell of lives lived in Worcester County
search_result.text:
In silence, they lie still amid the local landscape. Often, the only sound comes from rustling leaves as they fall in a chill October breeze. That said, according to some visitors, other sounds might be heard, including the laughter of children.

As such, they often draw historians, folklorists, paranormal investigators, and the merely curious. But whatever beliefs a person has about the supernatural, one thing is known for certain: in our local cemeteries, one can find not only secrets of the dead, but stories of those who lived.

Among them: people who were enslaved, treated as property both by law and custom. But like everyone, they had hopes, dreams, and humanity. And, they had names, to be remembered: Thomas. Flova. And those whose names were not recorded, or which are now unreadable due to weather, wear or damage.

In the same earth lies graves of those who held others in bondage, and so the ground itself becomes a place of history's terrible reckoning.

There are those who went to their graves early, from injuries sustained in war, or from diseases whose causes were little understood, but whose toll was writ large in death, and grief.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

There are inventors, such as a Shaker by name of Elijah Myrick, who nudged society forward with simple and practical tools, such as a cast-iron chimney cap. There are those whose name has gained renown, including one fellow who came to be known as "Grizzly Adams." And speaking of grizzly, there was a time when wearing a beard could get a man infamy and even dire punishment. So it went for one Joseph Palmer, in Leominster.

As Halloween nears, places of burial may find themselves a particular lure for those in search of ghosts, or rumors of ghosts. They are places to visit to learn, understand, and to pay respects.

In putting together these brief cemeteries of some of the region's most striking graves and cemeteries, there are rules, written and unwritten, that should always be observed:

Respect local visiting times. A night visit might be tempting, but it's almost universally prohibited except by special permissions.

Many headstones are attractive for grave-rubbing, but if not done correctly, this can damage delicate stones. If you don't have permission and don't know how to do it properly, just don't do it.

Yes, the atmosphere of many cemeteries lend themselves to spooky photo shoots and TikTok videos, but the same courtesies apply. Get any required permissions, or look for other locations.

Above all, cemeteries and graves are places of sanctity. Learn, listen, and as the saying goes, leave nothing but footsteps, take nothing that does not belong to you, and bring with you the knowledge that graves can bestow upon the living.

Rural Cemetery in Worcester

Rural Cemetery in Worcester ‚Äî more commonly known as Grove Street Cemetery ‚Äî is definitely haunted ... not by ghosts or vampires, but by history. A beautifully landscaped cemetery established in 1838 and still active today, the cemetery is the final resting place of many of the families and towering figures who built the city. Indeed, names written on tombstones and mausoleums are echoed on public buildings, parks and more across the county: Thayer, Crompton, Bancroft, Clark and more. For a history buff, the cemetery is a touchstone to the city‚Äôs past, a reminder that, in many ways, the people who built the city and made it what is today are still with us today. For journalism aficionados, there‚Äôs one resident who stands above all others: Isaiah Thomas Sr.

Thomas was the publisher of the Massachusetts Spy, a Revolutionary War-era newspaper which was one of the country‚Äôs first, and one of the first to take an editorial stand against the British in the days leading up to the war. Although the editorials were written under pseudonyms, Thomas was forced to retreat to Worcester, where he continued publishing.

Thomas‚Äô early resistance to British oppression was one of the sparks that lit the Revolution, so it seems strange that his tomb ‚Äì conveniently placed near the cemeteries entrance ‚Äì is rather nondescript, only identifiable by a plaque, although someone thought to put a small American flag in front of the grave, giving Thomas a modicum of the respect he deserves.

Wandering the paths aimlessly from there, one can meander into several of the city‚Äôs forefathers. The tomb of Jonas G. Clark ‚Äì founder of Clark University ‚Äì is clean and polished, practically glistening in the morning sun. Others are more worn with time. (It should be noted that several of the graves, including Thomas‚Äô, where relocated from cemeteries on the Worcester Common and Mechanics Street). History ‚Äì and the cemetery‚Äôs caretakers ‚Äì have been kind to the markers. But, time has taken its toll. One marker seems to simply be a rough-hewn stone, inscribed with only the words, ‚ÄúThe Inn of a traveler on her way to Jerusalem." If there was ever any other identifier on the stone, it‚Äôs no longer visible.

Perhaps the most strikingly beautiful and well-maintained mausoleum belongs to music teacher Walter Scott Kennedy and his wife, Ellen Frances Rogers ‚Äî who was reputed to be the wealthiest woman in Worcester in the early 20th century.

The couple also left the city Elm Park‚Äôs Rogers-Kennedy Memorial, also known as ‚ÄúThe New England Settlers.‚Äù Visitors can peek through the windows inside the mausoleum, which is as clean and well-kept as the building‚Äôs outside. On the walls are inscribed the words, ‚ÄúDeath is no departure but arrival/no falling asleep, but waking/It is life which is the night, and death is daybreak.‚Äù

All told, Rural Cemetery is an inspiring place to visit, almost every inch of its beautiful grounds punctuated by some piece of Worcester history, long-gone specters of yesterday echoing quietly to remind the city of its past, lest it be forgotten. ‚Äï Victor D. Infante

Evergreen Cemetery in Leominster

Leominster‚Äôs Evergreen Cemetery has an oddly appropriate name, given the number of people buried there whose stories resonate today. Families in the city have buried their deceased relatives there for more than 150 years. Near the wrought-iron front gate, rows of small marble footstones mark the graves of U.S. military veterans of many wars and conflicts in the distant and not-so-distant past. .

Across from 248 Main St. lies a grave marker famous enough that someone created a Google Maps tag for its location. The first thing that draws your eyes to the marble stone isn‚Äôt the name, Joseph Palmer, but the carving of Palmer himself, with an enormous, long, Santa Claus-esque beard that became highly controversial in Leominster during his time.

After serving in the War of 1812, Palmer returned and began growing out his facial hair, a daring move at a time when men were expected to be clean-shaven, and everyone was expected to follow such rules.

Author Jeff Belanger, who researches and writes about New England lore, devoted a 2021 episode to Palmer's story in the New England Legends Podcast, which Belanger cohosts with Ray Auger. Belanger cited an 1890 Boston Globe article that stated Palmer grew the beard because of his Christian faith, but was subsequently accused by his pastor of worshiping the devil.

‚ÄúWhen people stick out because of the way they choose to dress, style their hair, or in this case, wear their facial hair, other folks take notice, and for whatever reason, some people get mad about the nonconformists,‚Äù Belanger said during the episode.

In May 1830, Palmer was walking through Fitchburg when four men armed with razors surrounded him, held him down, and tried to shave off his beard. He managed to escape by stabbing two of them with a pocketknife, but he was arrested for assault. He pled not guilty and was jailed for 15 months.

Palmer kept the beard for the rest of his life. He died in1873. Beneath the carving on Palmer‚Äôs tombstone, above his name, there‚Äôs an inscription: ‚ÄúPersecuted for wearing the beard.‚Äù

Due east of Palmer‚Äôs grave where the cemetery meets the trees, there is a long strip of grass without headstones or names, the legacy of a pandemic that ravaged Leominster 100 years before COVID-19.

During the 1918 influenza pandemic, one of the deadliest in recorded history, 20 unidentified residents who succumbed to the virus were buried in one unmarked mass grave at Evergreen.

In late 2018, a century after the 1918 flu and only one year before COVID-19 was first detected in China‚Äôs Hubei province, the Leominster Historical Commission held a memorial ceremony for the unnamed influenza victims.

‚ÄúThe bodies would decompose, and the people were afraid of infection, so they had to be immediately buried,‚Äù commission chairman Don Piermarini told the Sentinel & Enterprise. ‚ÄúThe health department wanted you to get rid of that body as fast as possible.‚Äù

Within two years of that ceremony, when COVID-19 ripped through the world, mass graves and virus fatalities would re-enter the nationwide public consciousness. In April 2020, as New York City experienced catastrophic COVID death tolls, morgues became overfilled, and on Hart Island, where New York buries its unidentified or unclaimed bodies, 138 people were buried in one week.

There were other parallels between the 1918 flu and the most intense period of the COVID-19 pandemic.

In both crises, Leominster shut down public gatherings of any kind, and residents were expected to wear masks that covered their noses and mouths in order to prevent virus particles from spreading through the air. Both viruses had, and COVID-19 still has, the potential to cause lifelong damage to survivors‚Äô bodies.

In 2012, the Leominster Historical Society placed a marker on the Evergreen Cemetery mass grave, and though grass has grown over some of its corners, it‚Äôs still noticeable in the wide grass between two rows of older headstones.

The marker reads, ‚ÄúHere are buried some of the victims of the 1918 ‚Äì 1919 influenza pandemic. May they rest in peace.‚Äù ‚Äï Meg Trogolo

Hope Cemetery in Worcester

Sitting between St. John's and Notre Dame Cemeteries, Hope Cemetery is one of the oldest remaining burial grounds in the area.

In autumn, 168 acres of rolling land is illuminated by the brilliant colors of the surrounding fall foliage, a crisp breeze keeps visitors comfortable as they walk the incredibly clean grounds.

Established in 1852, the cemetery replaced at least six other local burial grounds were deemed overcrowded, with bodies of the deceased exhumed and relocated there. Thus, Hope Cemetery became Worcester's second garden cemetery, with a focus not only on those buried there, but also but the environment for those coming to visit their loved ones.

As with many cemeteries dating to the distant past, several ghost stories that go hand-in-hand with the cemetery between Webster Street and Hope Avenue. In the past, visitors have reported hearing children's laughter, specifically near a statue of Christ holding an angel. Other stories tell of a tall woman who tends to the flowers, but who always seems to disappear when approached.

The grounds are owned and operated by the city of Worcester, and burials take place year-round, with an average of 250 each year.

There are a number of notable internments including Elizabeth Bishop, considered one of the most important and distinguished American poets of the 20th century. Loring Coes, the inventor of the Monkey wrench has a family plot. Abby Kelly Foster, a 19th century feminist, and her husband Stephen Foster, an abolitionist are buried, as well as Robbert Goodard, the inventor of the first liquid-fueled rocket.

According to the Friends of Hope Cemetery, "Any citizen of Worcester has the right to be buried in Hope Cemetery. If the person or the family is unable to pay for burial, space is provided without cost."

It is the diversity within the cemetery that is most catching. With specific sections for Civil War veterans including members of the 54th Massachusetts Infantry Regiment ‚Äî one of the first Black regiments to fight in the Civil War ‚Äî religious groups and sects such as Orthodox Christian and a Jewish section with a completely different design. On top of the specific sections, there is an amalgamation of public plots; Worcester residents from all walks of life lie next to one another peaceful and at rest.

Myriad languages decorate a plethora of headstones and monuments. Through etchings, many celebrate the lives lived. Some unique items could be seen on gravestones during a recent visit, including coins, small Mancala pieces, envelopes, and a chrome balloon animal in the style of Jeff Koons. Traditionally, leaving coins and other items, a tradition dating at least to Roman times, signifes respect, including for military veterans.

Whether visiting a loved one, taking a historical trip to see one of Hope Cemetery's notable residents, or trying to hear the laughter of ghostly children, Hope Cemetery is a stunning place to spend an afternoon. ‚Äï Sarah Barnacle

Bay Path Cemetery in Charlton

When people think of John ‚ÄúGrizzly‚Äù Adams, a hunter who rose to fame in the 1800s by training bears to perform, they picture him in California, where he moved during the 1849 gold rush and made his name. Or, they think of the popular 1970s TV series, with the late Dan Haggerty in the title role.

However, Adams hailed from Massachusetts, raised in Medway, and a distant cousin of President John Adams, according to information on findagrave.com and other sources. His final resting place is in Charlton‚Äôs Bay Path Cemetery, on a little hill near the center of town surrounded by historic stone walls.

Born in 1812, Adams spent his younger years working for a circus, hunting and catching wild animals in northern New England‚Äôs forests. In 1849, he went west to try his luck searching for gold, but instead found himself back at the intersection of trapping and show business, including working with circus showman P.T. Barnum.

Some seven Adams family gravestones stand in a row at Bay Path, not far from the cemetery‚Äôs Muggett Hill Road entrance, including ‚ÄúGrizzly‚Äù Adams‚Äô parents, sister, wife, and children. The tallest of them, decorated with a carving of a man and a bear, belongs to Grizzly himself.

In addition to Adams‚Äô original gravestone, the Charlton Historical Society placed a shorter marble stone a few feet away in 1976, reading ‚ÄúGrave of Grizzly Adams.‚Äù

Many who fought in the American Revolution are also buried at Bay Path Cemetery, notably John Spurr, who threw English tea into Boston Harbor as part of the 1773 Boston Tea Party, and who fought in the 1775 Battle of Bunker Hill. A marker next to Spurr‚Äôs grave commemorates his eight years in the Continental Army.

Spurr settled in Charlton after the war and built a house at 27 Main St., close to the cemetery, and which is on the National Registry of Historic Places. He died in 1816 and is buried next to several relatives, a few feet from the stone wall that separates the cemetery from Dresser Hill Road.

Curiously, historical records show two men named John Spurr who participated in the Boston Tea Party. The other John Spurr died in 1822, is buried in Providence, Rhode Island, and, according to a 2023 WPRI Channel 12 article, also has a marker next to his grave denoting military service in the American Revolution.

Moses Dodge, born in Sutton in 1762, also served in the Continental Army‚Äôs Massachusetts regiment. Dodge, his son Gibbs Dodge, and other members of his family are buried in a tomb built into a small hillside next to the cemetery‚Äôs Muggett Hill Road entrance.

In the cemetery‚Äôs southeast corner is a stone column marking the graves of the Marble family, including Hiram Marble, who spent years digging for buried treasure every single day.

Marble‚Äôs story started two centuries before he was born, with an urban legend from the initial days of English colonization in Massachusetts. Early residents of Lynn passed down stories about a pirate named Tom Veal who stashed plundered valuables in a local cave, but was trapped inside when an earthquake struck.

Hiram Marble belonged to Charlton‚Äôs Spiritualist church, part of a popular 1800s movement that believed that the living could communicate with the spirits of the dead. In 1852, he claimed he had contacted Tom Veal through the barrier between this life and the next and Veal had told him the treasure was in a spot in Lynn called Dungeon Rock.

Marble moved his family to Lynn, bought the property that Dungeon Rock sat on, and began digging a tunnel with help from his son Edward, determining where to carve next by holding seÃÅances to contact Veal again.

Neither Hiram, who died in 1868, nor Edward ever found the buried treasure. Hiram himself is buried alongside his wife Arminda beneath a column at Bay Path Cemetery, and looking at his grave, it‚Äôs easy to wonder whether he ever found Tom Veal in the afterlife or tried to communicate with the living from the other side of the veil between worlds. ‚Äï Meg Trogolo

Meeting House Hill Cemetery in Princeton

Many cemeteries in colonial New England began as churchyards where parishioners were buried. Princeton‚Äôs Meeting House Hill Cemetery is among them, located on a hillside close to Mount Wachusett where the town‚Äôs first church, or meeting house, once stood.

The gravestones face west, and many of them are made from slate, which makes the carvings on them still easy to read centuries later. Several veterans of the American Revolution are buried there, including Capt. Elisha Allen, a farmer whose epitaph reads, ‚ÄúInhumanly murdered by Samuel Frost, July 16, 1793.‚Äù

Frost had been tried for the murder of his father in 1789, but was acquitted on grounds of insanity. Allen hired him to work on the farm, thinking it was safe, but he was proven wrong when Frost beat him to death with a garden tool while the two worked in a field. This time, Frost was convicted and given the death penalty, and he was hanged publicly in Worcester three months later on Oct. 31, Halloween night.

Near the center of Meeting House Hill is a trio of slate gravestones that tells pieces of a story tied to the end of slavery in Massachusetts.

Kwaku ‚ÄúQuock‚Äù Walker was born into slavery in Central Massachusetts in the 1750s, and grew up working alongside his family on James Caldwell‚Äôs farm in Barre.

Caldwell and his wife promised Walker that on his 21st birthday, he would be free, but Caldwell died before he could fulfill that promise. His wife remarried a man named Nathaniel Jennison, who refused to honor that promise. Walker left the Jennison farm, but was caught and beaten.

In 1781, Walker sued Jennison for assault and battery in the Worcester County Court of Common Pleas in the first of a string of cases.

In the end, the court ruled that he was a free man. Chief Justice William Cushing told the courtroom that ‚Äúslavery is inconsistent with our own conduct and Constitution and there can be no such thing as perpetual servitude of a rational creature.‚Äù

Moses Gill, a justice on the court who lived in Princeton, ruled in two of those cases, and one aspect of the Walker story that isn‚Äôt often told is that Gill was an enslaver himself.

Gill enslaved at least three Black workers as domestic servants in his Princeton home. They are buried in a row at Meeting House Hill Cemetery beneath small, elaborately carved gravestones near the Gill family plot.

One is Flova, a woman who died at 41 years old in 1778. Another is Thomas, a man who died at 89 years old in 1782. A chip has fallen off the top corner of the third stone, removing the name of the man buried there, but the bottom of the stone says he died at 39 in 1776.

Each slate stone is engraved with a face surrounded by swirled designs and bears the deceased‚Äôs name, date of death, age at death, and one more piece of information: ‚Äúa Negro Servant to the Hon. Moses Gill Esq.‚Äù

Engravings such as the ones on their gravestones were expensive at the time. In1953, Ethel Mirick wrote in the Princeton News that Thomas‚Äô long life ‚Äúwas bespeaking of the care which Gill bestowed upon his black servants.‚Äù

However, as the saying goes, even a gilded cage is still a cage.

Though the church that once stood above it is gone, replaced by houses with views of the Boston skyline dozens of miles away, the markers of the past remain, serving as a reminder that American slavery was not limited to areas south of the Mason-Dixon line ‚Äî white colonists enslaved African families in classic, picturesque New England towns like Princeton, too. ‚Äî Meg Trogolo

Shaker Cemetery in Harvard

Along Harvard's Shaker Road, your eye might be drawn to a stone wall, typically of many found in New England, and a simple white gate with a sign that reads, Harvard Shaker Cemetery, 1971-1918. What's different about this cemetery, however, is that very few graves are marked by traditional stones. The majority are white, cast-iron signs, pocked with rust, and with the names of the deceased written on a broad banner at the top.

The curious shape has prompted the nickname, "Lollipop Cemetery," which belies both the gravitas of this resting place, and the lives of those who are interred here.

The Shakers were and are a religious and social community who left an indelible stamp on the town of Harvard, and the region. Almost unique historically among faith movements, they embraced gender and racial equality, with both male and female leaders.

The Harvard Historical Society relates that at least 331 Shakers were buried here between 1792 and 1929. In the 1850s, the village population peaked at about 200, with members' landholdings totaled more than 2,000 acres. But in the Civil War era, the population dropped dramatically, including the departure of some members.

In 1879, the Shakers started replacing many stone markers with the cast-iron ones, with a stone marker reading, "Harvard Shakers" added by the town, which in 1945 would come into possession of the cemetery.

"It is pretty unusual looking, and that is one of the things that attracts people to it," said Judy Warner, assistant to the board of the Harvard Historical Society. "The cemetery was one of the first things the Shakers did after they settled in Harvard."

Work on the cemetery began in earnest in 1792. "They fenced and cleared an acre of land. It took them eight days with four yolk of oxen to make the stone walls around it. There are journal entries about that," Warner said. The last recorded burial in the cemetery took place in 1929.

As to why the Shakers eventually replaced most of the stone markers with the cast-iron ones, Warner said the reason was likely practical, with problem-solving and practicality as a hallmark of Shaker beliefs. But there's something more: while the cast-iron markers bear names, Warner noted that in many Shaker settlements, graves often were marked with stones that simply read, "Shakers."

Some graves belong to people, including children, who died very young, not unusual in a time when diseases and accidents often took an early toll. However, many of those interred lived long and apparently healthy lives, including Ezra B. Newton, a 47-year member of the Shaker community, who lived to 101.

"The Shakers were sort of noted for longevity. They had a reasonably good life, compared to the general population," Warner said. "They often attributed their good health to the water that they had, and actually later sold Shaker Spring Waters, and they touted the health benefits." This water came from a now-extinct spring that ran from Harvard's Shaker Village under land now part of Route 2.

As for Newton, he gained prominence locally, with a celebration in 1895 to mark his 100th birthday.

The cemetery has 12 graves belonging to the Myrick family, including Elijah Myrick, a Shaker elder and trustee of some 40 years, held patents for several inventions, including a type of cast-iron chimney cap.

Warner observed, "The Shakers were quite different from some other communities in that they loved modernization. They were not loathe to accept new ideas. They wanted to be up to date."

Warner is not only a keeper of history; she's also a neighbor to the cemetery. Although most visitors treat the cemetery respectfully, it has been a target of vandalism, and theft of the striking markers. "People should just be respectful and not damage anything, or think they need a souvenir," Warner said. "Some markers were broken, and have been repaired."

Warner notes something that is true of all cemeteries: "It is a holy place." ‚Äî Margaret Smith
