What‚Äôs at stake: A few months ago, the race appeared to clearly favor Fischer, who has broad financial and political backing in the deeply Republican state. That was the case until this summer, when polls conducted by Osborn‚Äôs campaign showed him and Fischer in a dead heat. Outside groups are pouring advertising money into both campaigns and the Cook Political Report recently changed the race‚Äôs leaning from solid-R to likely-R.

The race: Dueling abortion-related ballot initiatives

What‚Äôs on the ballot: Dueling abortion-related ballot initiatives: one aiming to expand abortion access in the state and the other looking to limit it.

What‚Äôs at stake: While multiple states will see abortion on the ballot this election, Nebraska is the first since the overturning of Roe v. Wade to put competing measures before voters. One measure backed by Protect Our Rights, a coalition of reproductive rights groups in the state, aims to enshrine the right to abortion when it is ‚Äúneeded to protect the life or health of the pregnant patient,‚Äù as well extend abortion access up to fetal viability. However, it does not list a specific number of weeks. The other sponsored by Protect Women and Children would enshrine Nebraska‚Äôs current 12-week ban in the state Constitution with exceptions for rape, incest and the life of the pregnant woman. It would allow the state legislature to pass narrower or complete bans in the future.

The race: Ballot measure on the legalization of medical cannabis

What‚Äôs on the ballot: Two measures aimed at legalizing medical marijuana.

What‚Äôs at stake: Nebraska is one of the last states where the use of medical cannabis is still illegal. To combat Nebraska‚Äôs single-issue law, the group is sponsoring two separate measures. One would decriminalize the use of medical marijuana and create protections for patients and caregivers. The other would legalize possessing, manufacturing, distributing, delivering and dispensing cannabis for medical purposes and create a state commission to regulate the drug.

‚Äî Maya Hoff, USA TODAY NETWORK

The race: U.S. Senate

Who‚Äôs running: Incumbent Democrat Jacky Rosen and Republican Sam Brown

What's at stake: Democrats‚Äô majority in the U.S. Senate is hanging by a thread, and Nevada‚Äôs seat up for election this year is considered competitive. Rosen, who prides herself on being one of Congress‚Äô most bipartisan members, has an edge in the polls against Brown, an Army veteran who‚Äôs fully in former President Donald Trump‚Äôs camp. If Trump wins Nevada ‚Äî the presidential race is within a single percentage point in the polls ‚Äî his coattails could help Brown. In 2022, Catherine Cortez Masto ‚Äî a well-liked incumbent Democrat with support from numerous prominent Republicans ‚Äî won her U.S. Senate race by only about 8,000 votes. The Senate race may be a squeaker again.

The race: Ranked-choice voting

What‚Äôs on the ballot: A ‚Äúyes‚Äù vote on the initiative would create primaries where the top five candidates regardless of party would move on to the general election.

What's at stake: This ballot race could upend Nevada politics for years to come by allowing nonpartisans ‚Äî who outnumber Republicans and Democrats in the state ‚Äî to participate in partisan primaries for state and federal races. Currently only Republicans and Democrats can vote in their own party‚Äôs primary races. Supporters think the initiative will create less extreme candidates because candidates will need to appeal to voters across the political spectrum, and they say voters will have more choice because often only the two candidates with the most money get on the November ballot. Opponents say it‚Äôll create confusion and could diminish the chances of independent candidates who would now have to compete with major party candidates in primaries. Only three states currently have ranked-choice voting: Alaska, Maine and Hawaii.

The race: Washoe County Question 1 ‚Äî library funding

What‚Äôs the ballot: Continue a dedicated funding stream for the Washoe County Library System or give the county commission more oversight of library programs.

What's at stake: As part of the culture wars in a swing county of a swing state, Reno-area libraries have been the scene of heated protests and increased security. Of the 22 book challenges last year in Nevada libraries ‚Äî most of those over LGBTQ+ content ‚Äî all were in Washoe County. This summer, the library system ended Drag Queen Story Hours at its libraries, citing ‚Äúviolence against staffers ‚Ä¶ perpetrated by a small group of very vocal, very aggressive protesters.‚Äù A Drag Queen Story Hour protester ‚Äî Bruce Parks, chair of the Washoe County Republican Party ‚Äî co-authored the official ballot argument against continuing the library‚Äôs dedicated funding stream. The dedicated funding stream represents about a quarter of the library system's budget. If the initiative fails, the library would have to appeal to elected officials to make up that shortfall.

‚Äî Reno Gazette Journal, USA TODAY NETWORK

Back to the top

The race: Governor

Who is running: Republican former U.S. Sen. Kelly Ayotte faces Democrat former Manchester Mayor Joyce Craig in an open seat race to succeed Gov. Chris Sununu, who has been the state‚Äôs popular Republican governor for eight years.

What‚Äôs at stake: Democrats are hoping to take back the governor's office in New Hampshire for the first time since 2016. The most competitive governor‚Äôs race in the country, Ayotte benefits from name recognition, while Craig is bolstered by Vice President Kamala Harris‚Äô popularity in the state. Ayotte‚Äôs poor relationship with Trump as well as his lack of popularity in the state means she will likely have to run far ahead of the former president to win the seat. She has also faced attacks on her past votes on abortion policies, while Craig has faced attacks over homelessness in Manchester. While the state has trended more Democratic in federal elections in recent years, the state government has been controlled by Republicans. Ayotte currently holds a narrow lead over Craig in the polls.

The race: 1st Congressional District

Who is running: Incumbent Democratic U.S. Rep. Chris Pappas is seeking a fourth two-year term to represent New Hampshire‚Äôs 1st Congressional District against Republican former New Hampshire Executive Councilor Russell Prescott.

What‚Äôs at stake: While New Hampshire‚Äôs 1st Congressional District has historically been a swing district, the moderate Pappas has dominated in recent years, proving his ability to win over voters from both parties. It is currently rated likely Democratic by the Cook Political Report. But Prescott is a less pro-Trump Republican opponent than Pappas has faced in the past, and his supporters hope this will help him unseat the popular incumbent and allow Republicans to take one of the two congressional seats.

The race: 2nd Congressional District

Who is running: Democrat Maggie Goodlander faces Republican Lily Tang Williams in this open race seat to replace retiring Rep. Annie Kuster.

What‚Äôs at stake: This seat leans likely Democratic, but features two unique candidates. A political newcomer, Goodlander is a former senior White House aide in President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration as well as the wife of National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan. She won a hard-fought primary against Kuster‚Äôs endorsed successor, Colin Van Ostern, proving herself to be a savvy campaigner and fundraiser. She is favored over Lily Tang Williams, whose American dream-esque story of escaping communist China allowed her to emerge victorious from a field of 13 Republican candidates.

The race: New Hampshire Executive Council District 3

Who is running: Republican incumbent Executive Councilor is seeking a third term to represent the Seacoast of New Hampshire in the five-body Executive Council. She is being challenged by Democrat former state Sen. Jon Morgan.

What‚Äôs at stake: New Hampshire‚Äôs little known Executive Council has been dominated by a Republican majority of 4-1 thanks to heavy gerrymandering and has faced controversy for the Republican‚Äôs repeated rejection of funding for Planned Parenthood and other reproductive clinics in the state that provide basic, low-cost reproductive health care. Stevens is favored to hold onto her seat in the Republican-leaning district, but Morgan‚Äôs record of winning in similar partisan districts means he could be a legitimate threat.

‚Äî Margie Cullen, USA TODAY NETWORK

Back to the top

The race: U.S. Senate

Who is running: Rep. Andy Kim, a Democrat, faces Republican Curtis Bashaw.

What‚Äôs at stake: The contest will determine the future of the seat long held by former Sen. Bob Menendez, who was convicted on federal bribery charges earlier this year and resigned from the Senate. Gov. Phil Murphy appointed George Helmy, his former chief of staff, to fill the seat until a successor is elected. Bashaw, a Cape May hotelier and businessman who is gay, has framed his campaign around moderate Republican positions familiar to New Jersey voters. Bashaw is pro-choice and has made his focus on government accountability and lowering spending. Kim, who has served in Congress since 2018 and was a diplomat in the administrations of former presidents Barack Obama and George W. Bush, prevailed in a competitive primary in which he held off a challenge from New Jersey first lady Tammy Murphy. Kim is focused on ensuring America‚Äôs global economic competitivesness and stabilizing affordability.

The race: 7th Congressional District

Who is running: Incumbent Rep. Tom Kean Jr. Faces Democrat Sue Altman

What‚Äôs at stake: New Jersey‚Äôs sprawling 7th Congressional District is a microcosm of the Garden State itself and stretches across 95 municipalities in six diverse counties. The district includes urban, suburban and rural communities. Kean, first elected in 2022 after a career in the New Jersey Senate, is a moderate Republican who is focused on affordability and lowering government spending. Kean has endorsed former President Donald Trump. Altman, the former executive director of the New Jersey Working Families Party, is running on a platform that espouses women's and reproductive rights, safeguarding democratic institutions and asserting America‚Äôs leadership on the world stage. The race is tight, but registered Republicans in the district outnumber Democrats by more than 14,000.

‚Äî USA TODAY NETWORK - New Jersey

Back to the top

The race: 2nd Congressional District

Who is running: Incumbent Democrat Gabe Vasquez faces Republican Yvette Herrell

What‚Äôs at stake: As a result of redistricting in 2020, New Mexico‚Äôs 2nd Congressional District stretches from its traditional boundaries encompassing the conservative southeastern part of the state to include portions of blue-leaning central and northern New Mexico. The seat has bounced back and forth between the parties since Republican Steve Pearce left it to seek election to the U.S. Senate, with Yvette Herrell gaining the seat in 2020 from Democrat Xotchitl Torres Small, who she challenged in 2018. Herrell then lost it in 2020 to Gabe Vasquez. Herrells‚Äô loyalty to Trump is reflected in her stand on abortion and enthusiasm for domestic drilling of crude oil and natural gas resources, positions in direct opposition to the governor and majority Democratic state legislature.

The race: U.S. Senate

Who is running: Incumbent Democrat Martin Heinrich faces Republican Nella Domenici

What‚Äôs at stake: Martin Heinrich has been at the forefront of developing New Mexico‚Äôs green energy transition, committing federal funds to establish wind and solar farms. Nella Domenici, daughter of Pete Domenici, a Republican who held New Mexico‚Äôs Senate seat for six terms, is following in her father‚Äôs conservative footsteps. Domenici says New Mexico should trade on its position in the Permian Basin, one of the largest oil producing regions in the U.S.

‚Äî USA TODAY NETWORK

Back to the top

The race: U.S. Senate

Who is running: Incumbent Democratic U.S. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, in office since 2009, is seeking another six-year term against Mike Sapraicone, a Long Island resident who owns a private security company.

What‚Äôs at stake: While Gillibrand is widely favored to win, New York state has seen some shifts in places from blue to red. Her margin of victory and where her numbers might slip from the 2018 election will be telling about New York‚Äôs political trends.

The race: Proposition 1

What‚Äôs on the ballot: New York has one statewide ballot question for voters to decide this fall: whether to add abortion and LGBTQ rights to the state Constitution. New York's would ban discrimination based on "reproductive healthcare" and a host of other reasons unrelated to abortion, such as sexual orientation, national origin and age.

What‚Äôs at stake: At a time when such rights are under attack in much of the country, this ballot measure‚Äôs fate will be instructive.

The race: 17th Congressional district

Who‚Äôs running: First-term Republican Rep. Mike Lawler faces former Rep. Mondaire Jones.

What‚Äôs at stake: The 17th Congressional District, one of the nation's most hotly contested swing districts ‚Äî a seat Democrats lost in 2022 and need to recover to regain a House majority. Lawler eked out a narrow upset win in the suburbs north of New York City two years ago. If he retains his seat, that would reflect a reddening of these areas where residents have been concerned about immigration and crime. Jones is a former House member who saw his previous seat disappear in redistricting earlier this decade.

The race: 19th Congressional District

Who‚Äôs running: Republican Rep. Marc Molinaro is seeking a second term in a rematch against Democratic challenger Josh Riley, former Dutchess County executive and a former state Assembly member.

What‚Äôs at stake: In early autumn, this was the most expensive House race in the country, reflecting the importance of the seat in terms of which party will control Congress in 2025 and 2026.

‚Äî USA TODAY NETWORK - New York

Back to the top

The race: Governor

Who is running: Mark Robinson, the current Republican lieutenant governor, has caused shock waves in North Carolina and national politics for his incendiary comments, most recently after a CNN article alleged he made racist and sexual posts on a pornography message board, which he denies. Robinson, 56, is running against Josh Stein, the 58-year-old lawyer and current attorney general.

What‚Äôs at stake: Abortion and education have become key aspects of this race. Although he‚Äôs flipped on his abortion stance, Robinson in the recent past has supported tighter restrictions. Stein is an outspoken reproductive rights supporter and is endorsed by Planned Parenthood Votes! South Atlantic. These candidates are also on opposite ends when it comes to funding education. Stein is fighting for fully funding public schools, and Robinson is supporting taxpayer funded private school vouchers. Robinson also used his time in office to investigate possible indoctrination of schools.

The race: Superintendent of Public Instruction

Who is running: Republican Michele Morrow is a former missionary and homeschool curriculum developer and nurse who is running against Democrat Maurice (Mo) Green, a previous superintendent of Guilford County Schools and general counsel and deputy superintendent for Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools.

What‚Äôs at stake: Morrow, 53, has become a controversial candidate for her presence at the Jan. 6 riot and incendiary remarks posted on social media, recently posting on X that the ‚Äú+‚Äù in LGBTQ+ stands for ‚ÄúPedophilia.‚Äù Morrow supports private school vouchers and has said she wants an audit of federal money in North Carolina schools, claiming their money often comes with strings attached, WRAL reports. Green‚Äôs campaign has called Morrow a ‚Äúdangerous‚Äù choice for students, and he supports fully funding public schools and rejects using taxpayer money for private school vouchers. Green, 56, also hopes to partner more with outside community organizations to support children's education.

The race: North Carolina Supreme Court

Who is running: North Carolina Supreme Court Justice Allison Riggs is looking to keep her seat on the state‚Äôs high court after Gov. Roy Cooper appointed Riggs, a Democrat, to fill former Justice Mike Morgan‚Äôs slot on the bench in 2023, following his retirement. She is running against Jefferson Griffin, a Republican on the state court of appeals.

What's at stake: Republicans already hold a 5-2 majority on the state‚Äôs highest court, which in recent years has upheld gerrymandered maps that could give Republicans even greater control in the U.S. House. But if Riggs, a Democrat wins, her party will have the opportunity to regain that majority in 2028. Griffin is close with N.C. Supreme Court Justice Paul Newby. (Newby won his seat in 2020 by just 401 votes against Cheri Beasley.) So far this election, Griffin has raised $1.3 million, to Riggs‚Äô $1.1 million.

The race: Buncombe County Board of Commissioners chair

Who is running: Former Buncombe County Sheriff Van Duncan is running for chair of the county board of commissioners as an unaffiliated candidate. His opponent, Commissioner Amanda Edwards, a Democrat, faces a steep fundraising gap.

What's at stake: Duncan, a former Democrat, is trying to toe the line between parties. But he‚Äôs received sizable campaign contributions from notable area Republicans like former Congressman Charles Taylor. Buncombe County is home to Asheville and was hard hit be Tropical Storm Helene. Whoever wins will likely play a major role in the county's Helene recovery efforts.

‚Äî USA TODAY NETWORK

The race: Initiated Statutory Measure No. 5

What‚Äôs on the ballot: The measure creates a new chapter of the North Dakota Century Code related to the legalization of cannabis and related regulation, according to North Dakota‚Äôs Secretary of State website.

What's at stake: If approved, it would allow for the production, processing, and sale of cannabis and the possession and use of various forms of cannabis by individuals who are 21 years of age and older. It would also allow the state to regulate the industry and preserve employer rights regarding the use of cannabis products by employees, among its provisions. The measure includes revenues of $10,227,600, expenses of $8,324,275, and ‚Äúan undetermined amount of additional costs associated with behavioral health and social impacts for the 2025-2027 biennium,‚Äù the website states.

The race: Governor

Who is running: Michael (Coach) Coachman, an independent; Kelly Armstrong; a Republican; Merrill Piepkorn; a Democrat.

What's at stake: North Dakota caught a bit of attention this election season, when current Gov. Doug Burgum ended up on the short-list as a vice-presidential candidate for former President Donald Trump. Last year, Burgum briefly sought the Republican presidential nomination and in January, he announced he would not seek a third term as governor, leaving the race wide open.

‚Äî Shelly Conlon, Argus Leader, USA TODAY NETWORK

Back to the top

The race: U.S. Senate

Who is running: Three-term Democratic U.S. Sen. Sherrod Brown and Republican businessman Bernie Moreno

What‚Äôs at stake: Brown is one of the most vulnerable Democrats on the ballot this year ‚àí second only to Montana Sen. Jon Tester ‚àí and the outcome in Ohio could determine which party controls a closely divided U.S. Senate come January. Former President Donald Trump also won Ohio by 8 points in 2016 and 2020. Polls show Trump easily winning Ohio again. This is the first time Brown has been on the ballot the same day as Trump, who has endorsed Moreno.

The race: State Issue 1

What's on the ballot: A group called Citizens Not Politicians crafted a new way to draw districts and put the constitutional amendment on the ballot as Issue 1.

What's at stake: The proposal would replace the current politician-run commission with a 15-member citizen commission of five independents and five members each from the top two political parties, currently the Republicans and Democrats. Members couldn't be elected officials, lobbyists or political consultants. During the last redistricting cycle, lawmakers and elected officials repeatedly drew legislative maps deemed unconstitutional by the state Supreme Court. Currently, Ohio Republicans dominate the redistricting process and hold supermajorities in the state House and Senate.

The race: 3 seats on the Ohio Supreme Court

Who is running: Cleveland Democrat Melody Stewart and Cincinnati Republican Joe Deters, both incumbent justices, are facing off. Gov. Mike DeWine appointed Deters to an unexpired term but Deters decided to challenge Stewart for a full term. Cleveland Democrat Michael Donnelly, an incumbent, is being challenged by Cincinnati Republican Megan Shanahan, a Hamilton County Common Pleas Court judge making her first statewide run. Cleveland Democrat Lisa Forbes, an 8th District Appellate Court judge, and Columbus Republican Dan Hawkins, a Franklin County Common Pleas Court judge, are both running for the seat left open by Deters' decision to challenge Stewart.

What‚Äôs at stake: Republicans have held majority on the court for nearly 40 years. The Democrats are trying to reelect two incumbent justices and win an open seat. The GOP wants to expand its majority by sweeping all three races, which would give Republicans six of seven seats. Who controls the court has a major impact on issues including abortion and redistricting.

‚Äî The Columbus Dispatch, USA TODAY NETWORK

The race: Oklahoma Corporation Commission

Who is running: Republican Brian Bingman faces Democrat Harold Spradling and Libertarian Chad Williams in a race to replace outgoing Commissioner Bob Anthony. Bingman was the secretary of state until he stepped down last year to campaign for corporation commission.

What‚Äôs at stake: The influential Corporation Commission regulates public utilities, oil, gas and other energy sources, commercial transportation and petroleum storage tanks. The three-person commission has been the subject of recent turmoil after witnesses reported seeing Commissioner Todd Hiett grope a man while Hiett was extremely intoxicated at a conference in June. Hiett has refused to step down, and Anthony launched an investigation into his colleague‚Äôs behavior. Anthony‚Äôs replacement will now help determine how the commission moves forward.

The race: State Question 834

What‚Äôs on the ballot: A measure put on the ballot by Republican lawmakers asks voters to tweak part of the state Constitution that defines who can vote as a ‚Äúqualified elector.‚Äù

What‚Äôs at stake: While only a few words would change, supporters say the move is needed to make clear only people who are legal citizens of the U.S. can vote in Oklahoma elections. Critics say the proposed change is targeting issues that don‚Äôt exist ‚Äî routine audits of election results and voter rolls show the state‚Äôs election system is accurate and secure.

The race: 5th Congressional District, representing Oklahoma City and parts of central Oklahoma

Who is running: Incumbent Republican Rep. Stephanie Bice faces a challenge from Democrat Madison Horn, a cybersecurity expert.

What‚Äôs at stake: While Oklahoma is a solidly red state, the metro area district Bice and Horn are vying to represent is turning purple. If voters send Horn to Washington, D.C., she would be the state‚Äôs lone Democratic representative in Congress. Her odds remain long, however. While Democrats are gaining ground in and around Oklahoma City, they‚Äôre still outnumbered by Republican voters. Republican incumbents are on track to retain Oklahoma‚Äôs four other seats in the U.S. House.

‚Äî The Oklahoman, USA TODAY NETWORK

The race: Measure 118

What‚Äôs on the ballot: Measure 118, known as the Oregon Rebate, would raise the minimum corporate tax rate.

What‚Äôs at stake: Oregonians will decide whether to raise the minimum tax rate by 3% for corporations with Oregon sales above $25 million a year and distribute the proceeds to every Oregonian, beginning in 2025. Passage would make Oregon the first state with a universal basic income program. State analysts estimate the measure would increase corporate tax revenue by $1.3 billion during Oregon‚Äôs two-year budget cycle. Proponents say the measure would decrease the state poverty rate by ‚Äúrebating‚Äù some $1,600 a year to every resident. Opponents say the measure would result in increased costs and loss of businesses.

The race: 5th Congressional District

Who is running: Democrat Janelle Bynum is challenging incumbent Rep. Lori Chavez DeRemer, R-Oregon.

What‚Äôs at stake: In 2022, Chavez-DeRemer was the first Republican woman elected to represent Oregon in the U.S. House. Bynum twice beat Chavez-DeRemer for the Oregon legislature and seeks to flip the seat. Polls have designated the race as a ‚Äútoss-up.‚Äù

The race: Oregon attorney general

Who is running: Republican Will Lathrop and Democrat Dan Rayfield

What‚Äôs at stake: The race is Oregon‚Äôs first attorney general election since the state‚Äôs 2020 drug decriminalization measure was passed and later dismantled. Lathrop previously served as a deputy district attorney in Yamhill and Marion counties, while Rayfield has been a member of Oregon‚Äôs House of Representatives since 2015 and served as speaker of the House from February 2022 until the end of the 2024 legislative session. Democrat Ellen Rosenblum, who has been attorney general since 2012, announced her retirement in 2023. With more than $2 million in combined spending, the race is the most expensive of Oregon‚Äôs three statewide elections. Oregon‚Äôs last Republican attorney general left office in 1993.

The races: Mayor of Portland and Portland city councilors

Who is running: There are 19 people running for mayor, including three city commissioners, a trucking company leader, a stripper/author, and a nonprofit director. Ninety-eight candidates are running for 12 Portland City Council seats.

What‚Äôs at stake: The 2024 election will be the first using ranked-choice voting for the mayoral, auditor and city council races in Portland, Oregon's largest city. The new Portland mayor also will have a new job description. A voter-approved change in 2022 means the mayor will not have a vote on the Portland City Council unless there is a tie and will mostly serve in an administrative role.

‚Äî USA TODAY NETWORK

Back to the top

The race: U.S. Senate

Who is running: Incumbent Democratic U.S. Sen. Bob Casey is vying for his fourth term against Republican Dave McCormick, a former hedge fund CEO and high-ranking Treasury Department official during former President George W. Bush's administration.

What‚Äôs at stake: The Pennsylvania Senate seat is a must-win for Democrats seeking to retain control of the upper chamber, which they hold by a razor-thin margin. Casey, a fixture in Pennsylvania politics, has breezed through his past reelection battles. But McCormick does have the advantage of voter discontent with President Joe Biden and has worked hard to implicate Casey in the Democratic administration's perceived shortcomings on immigration and the economy. While the incumbent is favored, the race has narrowed, and a handful of polls show the two candidates locked in a dead heat.

‚Äî Bethany Rodgers, USA TODAY NETWORK

The race: 10th Congressional District

Who is running: Six-term incumbent Republican Scott Perry is facing perhaps his strongest opponent so far, Democratic challenger Janelle Stelson, a popular former TV news anchor.

What‚Äôs at stake: Control of the U.S. House could be on the ballot in this race. Perry, a former chair of the ultra-conservative House Freedom Caucus, has not faced strong opposition during his tenure in Congress in a conservative district. But Stelson, a Republican turned Democrat, has hammered Perry for his positions on reproductive rights and has cast the election as a choice between anti-democratic views and her commitment to democracy. Perry was on the front lines of President Donald Trump‚Äôs fight to overturn the 2020 election, an effort that led the U.S. Justice Department to launch an investigation and seize Perry‚Äôs cell phone via a search warrant. That investigation has not resulted in any charges, and Perry has denied any wrongdoing. Political observers predict a close race in a district that became more competitive after the most recent redistricting. Polls show the race in a dead heat.

‚Äî Mike Argento, York Daily Record, USA TODAY NETWORK

The race: 1st Congressional District

Who is running: Incumbent Republican U.S. Rep. Brian Fitzpatrick is seeking a fifth term against Army veteran and Apache helicopter pilot Ashley Ehasz, who lost against Fitzpatrick in 2022 but now has the backing of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee as a ‚Äútop-tier candidate‚Äù to flip a longtime red district in the Philadelphia suburbs.

What's at stake: The 1st District is one of 33 congressional races the DCCC has highlighted in its Red to Blue campaign to maintain or bolster control of the House. The southeastern Pennsylvania district has been under Republican leadership since 2011, with Fitzpatrick cementing a reputation as the most bipartisan member of congress. Ehasz‚Äôs campaign has pushed back on that neutral image, saying the incumbent‚Äôs bipartisanship won‚Äôt extend to reproductive rights and threats to democracy.

‚Äî Chris Ullery, Pennsylvania state investigative team, USA TODAY NETWORK

The race: Pennsylvania Senate, 49th District

Who is running: Two-term Republican incumbent Sen. Dan Laughlin faces a challenge from the former chair of the Erie County Democratic Party Jim Wertz, a first-time candidate.

What's at stake: Democrats see district, which covers nearly all of Erie County, as being among the seats they can flip to take over the state Senate. Laughlin and Wertz, who used to trade emails about politics, also are engaged in a civil lawsuit. Laughlin claims the weekly Erie Reader and Wertz defamed him by publishing an opinion piece by Wertz ‚Äî who was a contributing editor and writer for the publication before his state Senate bid ‚Äî that accused Laughlin and U.S. Rep. Mike Kelly of seeking a pardon over the 2020 election. Laughlin had signed an amicus brief that specifically stated it was not taking the side of either the plaintiff or the defendant in the case Texas v. Pennsylvania, which was a hail-Mary attempt to overturn the results of the presidential election.

‚Äî Matthew Rink, Pennsylvania state investigative team, USA TODAY NETWORK

The race: U.S. Senate

Who is running: Incumbent Democratic U.S. Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse is seeking a fourth term against Republican state legislator Patricia Morgan, who lists her occupation as "financial advisor."

What‚Äôs at stake: Whitehouse, 68, a former U.S. Attorney and Rhode Island attorney general, has been in the Senate since 2007, after he ousted Republican Lincoln Chafee. He is known for warning about the perils of climate change and "dark money" in campaign finances. Whitehouse was named Senate Budget Committee chair last year and turned much of its focus toward climate issues. More recently, he‚Äôs been one of the louder voices in Washington on term limits for the U.S. Supreme Court. She has attacked Whitehouse for supporting President Joe Biden on immigration and federal spending, among other issues. In announcing her candidacy, she took aim at inflation, the economy and "massive and wasteful federal spending."

The race: Ballot Question 1

What's on the ballot: Question 1 will determine whether there will be a constitutional convention

What‚Äôs at stake: If voters approve Question 1 on Nov. 5 there will be an election to choose 75 delegates who will meet at a time and place to be determined to recommend amendments to the state Constitution that would be put up for approval at another statewide election. The last time voters called for a convention was 1984, and past conventions have taken on many shapes and sizes, from the 1973 convening that lasted a month to the 1964 affair that lasted four years. The last one cost taxpayers $891,000, or about $2.5 million in today's money.

‚Äî Providence Journal, USA TODAY NETWORK

What‚Äôs at stake: The proposed change would alter one word of the state Constitution to have it read ‚Äúonly a citizen of the United States and of this State of the age of eighteen and upwards who is properly registered is entitled to vote as provided by law.‚Äù Although an investigation found no noncitizens were voting in the state‚Äôs elections, lawmaker

search_result.title: Oklahoma's Legislature has a history of passing unconstitutional laws
search_result.text:
Oklahoma laws on worker's compensation, trains stopped on the tracks, liquor distribution and medication abortions all have something in common.

Local state and federal courts have found these laws, crafted by Oklahoma's Legislature, are partially or wholly unconstitutional, although some of the rulings are still under appeal.

The Oklahoma Legislature has a history of passing bills that are later struck down by the courts as unconstitutional.

Passing laws that are later overturned by the courts is not an issue specific to Oklahoma. Nor is the trend limited to the current Republican-led leadership at the state legislature.

But critics say the legislature sometimes knowingly advances unconstitutional legislation, which they argue is a waste of time and taxpayer money when Oklahoma's attorney general has to defend those laws in court.

One Capitol observer said the number of unconstitutional bills in the Oklahoma Legislature has grown in recent years, with more constitutionally questionable bills making it to the governor's desk.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve always had some unconstitutional legislation, but in recent years, and in this session in particular, we‚Äôve seen that grow in volume,‚Äù said Nicole McAfee, director of policy and advocacy for the ACLU of Oklahoma. ‚ÄúThis year, we're seeing a lot of those sort of blatantly unconstitutional attacks on access to abortion care and attacks on protest rights advanced through the legislative process.‚Äù

Others are reading: Nearly 200 Oklahoma school districts suing state Education Board

Republican leaders of the Oklahoma House and Senate said their chambers never knowingly advance unconstitutional bills.

Constitutionality is subjective, and the courts reviewing the legality of laws is part of the government‚Äôs process of checks and balances, said House Speaker Charles McCall, R-Atoka.

‚ÄúThe Oklahoma House constantly discusses constitutionality in the legislative process and never knowingly advances anything unconstitutional,‚Äù McCall said in a statement. ‚ÄúConstitutionality subjectivity is why coequal legislative, executive and judicial branches have existed for checks and balances in Oklahoma and democracies everywhere since ancient Greece.‚Äù

Cost of unconstitutional legislation unknown

Attorney General Mike Hunter's office does not track how much it costs for state attorneys to defend Oklahoma laws that wind up embroiled in court battles.

Because the lawyers defending state laws in court are on staff at the attorney general's office, their time spent on a case can't be tallied as easily as the billable hours of a private-sector attorney.

The Solicitor General's unit, which is made up of five lawyers, is typically tasked with defending state laws, said Alex Gerszewski, a spokesman for the office. Typically two or three lawyers work on a case defending the constitutionality of a state law.

Hunter's office does not keep records on how many state laws its attorneys have defended.

"I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs any question that the legislature has passed unconstitutional legislation," said Senate Minority Leader Kay Floyd, a lawyer. Both Republicans and Democrats have done so, she said.

Floyd, D-Oklahoma City, has repeatedly sought information on how much it costs the attorney general's office to defend unconstitutional legislation, only to be told that information doesn't exist.

Oklahoma laws struck down in courts

The U.S. Supreme Court has struck down at least six Oklahoma state laws, including in 1976, a law that allowed women age 18 or older to buy low-point beer while denying that privilege to men until they were 21, which the nation's high court found violated the 14th Amendment's Equal Protection Clause.

But lower courts have struck down more.

From 2006 to 2016, Floyd, doing her own research, found local courts struck down as unconstitutional nearly 30 Oklahoma laws.

Critical race theory: Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt to decide on bill to ban teaching of theory

Common themes included laws to restrict abortions and violations of the state's single-subject rule that stipulates legislation may deal only with one main issue.

One of the most notable examples was when the Oklahoma Supreme Court ruled in 2015 a Ten Commandments monument at the state Capitol, which was placed there with approval from the legislature, violated the state's constitution that prohibits using public property to benefit a ‚Äúchurch denomination or system of religion.‚Äù

Floyd suggested concerns about the constitutionality of legislation should be addressed early on in the legislative process, either with input from the attorney general's office or from a constitutional lawyer.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs bad for the state," she said. "It costs us money. It costs us reputation, and whatever we tried to accomplish with that bill, is not going to be accomplished."

Oklahoma anti-abortion bills raise questions

The Oklahoma Legislature this year has advanced a slate of anti-abortion bills that critics say are blatantly unconstitutional.

Representatives from Planned Parenthood Great Plains and Trust Women say many of the anti-abortion bills that have advanced through the Legislature are specifically designed to limit access to abortions, which conflicts with U.S. Supreme Court rulings that legalized the practice.

‚ÄúAgain, the Oklahoma Legislature is focused on radical and unconstitutional legislation that will only be thrown out of the courts,‚Äù said Julie Burkhart, founder and CEO of Trust Women. ‚ÄúI would rather they spend their time on restoring access to health care to Oklahomans than wasting time on restricting the ability of people to get safe and quality health care.‚Äù

Trust Women operates an abortion clinic in Oklahoma City.

Oklahoma's GOP-led legislature has always pushed anti-abortion legislation, but some are optimistic that political shifts at the U.S. Supreme Court will prompt the court to re-evaluate its abortion precedents.

Abortion in Oklahoma: Stitt signs bill to ban abortion if SCOTUS rules

Gov. Kevin Stitt recently signed bills to revoke the medical license of doctors who perform abortions that are not medically necessary to prevent "irreversible physical impairment" or death of the mother and limit which physicians can perform the procedure.

Stitt also signed a "heartbeat" bill that would prohibit an abortion if a fetal heartbeat can be detected, which in some cases, can be detected as early as six weeks into a pregnancy ‚Äî before many women know they are pregnant.

Any doctor who performs an abortion after a heartbeat is detected could be charged with homicide under the new law.

Asked about the possibility that Oklahoma faces legal challenges over these new laws, Stitt said, "we'll let the courts work out if any of those get overturned."

The heartbeat bill is one of the many unlawful and unconstitutional bills introduced this year that attempts to end abortion in Oklahoma, said Gloria Pedro, of Planned Parenthood Great Plains.

Former Gov. Mary Fallin vetoed legislation in 2016 that contained similar restrictions for doctors performing abortions, saying she did not believe it could withstand a constitutional challenge, Pedro said.

Citing the 10th Amendment, which talks about the government powers granted to the states, Sen. Julie Daniels, R-Bartlesville, who supported the "heartbeat" bill, suggested the U.S. Supreme Court overstepped its authority by legalizing abortion with its landmark Roe v. Wade decision.

‚ÄúI do not have the authority to overturn that decision,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI believe fully that it violates the 10th Amendment, so with the authority I have been given, I will work tirelessly to limit abortion in this state until the day comes that that wrongly decided decision is overturned and the authority for making these decisions about preserving life is returned to the states where it belongs.‚Äù

Republican legislators also introduced bills to further regulate medication abortions, in which women early on in their pregnancies can take a regimen of two pills to induce an abortion.

Stitt also signed a so-called "trigger bill" that would prohibit abortions in Oklahoma if the U.S. Supreme Court ever overturns Roe v. Wade or Planned Parenthood v. Casey that established the constitutional right for women to seek an abortion.

There is optimism among those who oppose abortion that the U.S. Supreme Court, with its Trump-appointed conservative majority, will overturn its previous precedents on abortion, said Sen. Nathan Dahm, R-Broken Arrow. Specifically, conservatives want the court to overturn Roe v. Wade and allow states to further restrict abortions.

Dahm, who opposes abortion, cited the 1992 Planned Parenthood v. Casey decision as an example of when the high court reviewed its precedent on abortion.

"It is rare that the courts will change their precedents, but it does happen, especially when there are things that have changed in society," Dahm said. "Even in Roe v. Wade, (the justices) talked about how they would revisit it as technology advanced and as their understanding of life and conception advanced."

Constitutional clash over federal overreach

The discussion over unconstitutional legislation at the Oklahoma Legislature recently came to a head when Senate Pro Tem Greg Treat alleged a top priority for the Oklahoma House was unconstitutional.

Treat refused to hear in its original form a bill that sought to curb federal overreach and push back against the Biden administration by allowing Oklahoma‚Äôs attorney general or a majority vote of the legislature to declare presidential executive orders unconstitutional.

Treat, R-Oklahoma City, called House Bill 1236 a clear violation of the separation of powers.

"Believe me, it would be much easier politically for me to let (HB) 1236 go to the governor‚Äôs desk as is, beg him to sign it and know that the courts are going to throw it out, but to give people false hope is not what I‚Äôm here for," Treat said.

Saying the legislation seeks to assert Oklahoma‚Äôs 10th Amendment rights, McCall, the House Speaker and one of the bill's authors, has defended the legislation supported by most House Republicans.

The 10th Amendment says powers not delegated to the federal government are reserved to the states. However, the Supremacy Clause of the U.S. Constitution states the federal constitution and federal law are the supreme law of the land and generally take precedence over state laws.

‚ÄúExercising constitutional rights is not unconstitutional,‚Äù McCall said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe bill codifies in state law the 10th Amendment rights granted to states under the U.S. Constitution and creates a method of evaluating certain federal actions at the state level.‚Äù

Court rulings on the constitutionality of legislation can give state lawmakers guidance on what they can and cannot regulate.

For example, an Oklahoma City federal judge recently said a 2019 state law that prevented trains from blocking streets for longer than 10 minutes ran afoul of federal law. The ruling is under appeal.

"The bill itself was not ruled unconstitutional; the 10-minute requirement within it was," said McCall, who authored the legislation. "In the ruling, the judge found and affirmed states have the right to regulate train crossings. Should the appeal not succeed, the ruling gives the Legislature guidance to modify the 10-minute requirement to be consistent with the ruling."

Derailing unconstitutional legislation

Treat said since he has been the leader of the Oklahoma Senate, he has not allowed blatantly unconstitutional legislation to advance.

There may be laws that don't stand up in court for nuanced reasons, but Treat said he's unwilling to pass legislation that lawmakers know will not hold up in court.

"If I believe that something is inherently, on its face, unconstitutional, I have not given it a hearing," Treat said. "Or we have substantially changed it."

Even before HB 1236 advanced to the Senate, some legislators cried foul.

House Democrats argued the legislation is clearly unconstitutional because challenges to presidential executive orders and other federal actions are reviewed by the courts, not state legislatures.

It goes back to the fundamentals of government and the duties of the three branches of government, said Rep. Regina Goodwin, D-Tulsa.

‚ÄúHB 1236 is a fine example of an unconstitutional bill,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt see this last session when President Trump was in office. You didn‚Äôt see any of this concern then about the federal government and federal overreach.‚Äù

Goodwin is among legislative Democrats that have tried to track how many pieces of Oklahoma legislation have been found to be unconstitutional.

According to Goodwin, from 2010 to 2013, 14 laws were found to be unconstitutional ‚Äî amounting to less than 1% of the bills that became law during that time period.

Goodwin can also rattle off a list of more recent laws that have been overturned by the courts.

She pointed to legislation from 2019 that would have required the most popular wine and spirits brands be made available to all wholesale distributors, which ran counter to State Question 792 that allowed wine and spirits manufacturers to pick and choose their distributors.

Also overturned was State Question 755, which banned the use of Sharia law in state courts. The legislature referred the measure to the ballot where it passed with 70% approval.

The Oklahoma Supreme Court also found a 2011 tort reform law that placed a legislative cap on damages for pain and suffering to be unconstitutional. Then-Gov. Fallin signed the measure into law despite concerns from some that the legislation was unconstitutional.

"It's a way to continue to stir the pot when they know it's unconstitutional," Goodwin said of the GOP majority in the legislature. "They kind of pass these bills with a sneer and a smile."

search_result.title: TLH 200: The 200 people who shaped Tallahassee ahead of ...
search_result.text:
James Call and Greg Tish

TLH 200 writers

The TLH 200: Gerald Ensley Memorial Bicentennial Project is proud to present our rolling list of 200 people who laid the foundation and contributed to the growth of the civil society we find today in Tallahassee.

As the city commemorates the 200th anniversary of its founding, the Tallahassee Democrat and Real Talk 93.3 have cast a wide net to find artists, educators, civil rights leaders, politicians, athletes, builders, business titans and neighborhood icons who have earned a spotlight.

But we need your help.

You can email your suggestions of candidates to be profiled and other suggestions to history@tallahassee.com. And listen to Greg Tish‚Äôs morning show on Real Talk 93.3 where we'll discuss the legacy of these history makers.

The only condition is that those featured below must be deceased. Ten names will be added periodically, so be sure to check back for updates into 2025.

Without further ado, here are the first 100 names.

Justice James Diament Westcott, Jr. (1839 - 1887)

Tallahassee born James Diament Westcott III, who preferred ‚ÄúJunior‚Äù rather than James the Third, had a knack for law and politics.

By the age of 28, Westcott served as the Assistant Secretary of the Florida Senate, the private secretary of Governor Madison S. Perry, and as a captain in the Confederate States Army.

After the war he was elected as a Leon County representative to the Florida House.

The year he turned 30, he was elected attorney general. It was a remarkable feat because Westcott ran as a Democrat in the year a new Florida Constitution gave voting rights to freed slaves who registered as Republicans and the GOP won in landslides up and down the ballot.

Within a few weeks of the election Republican Gov. Harrison Reed appointed Westcott to the Florida Supreme Court, making him the youngest justice in Florida history.

He would serve for 17 years and would write 267 opinions ‚Äì the most in Florida history.

Westcott received his entire academic education at West Florida Seminary ‚Äì which would become Florida State University, for which he was eternally grateful.

Upon his death, he left his entire estate to West Florida Seminary. The principal would produce about $69,000 annually.

That was enough to provide a financial lifeline for the struggling institution ‚Äì the stability needed for the school to evolve into a state-supported university. Today, a portion of the proceeds goes toward financial assistance for low-income students.

Westcott died in 1887 and is buried in Tallahassee‚Äôs Old City Cemetery. In 1936, Florida State University named its administration building in his honor.

Gilbert Chandler (1889 - 1978)

In 1925, a Minnesota asparagus farmer was disappointed when he stopped for a night in Tallahassee ‚Äì he found no place to stay, not even space to pitch a tent.

The disappointment would lead Gilbert Chandler to build a Tallahassee landmark, The Cottages of Lake Ella.

Chandler had $2,000 in his pocket when he ventured out of the land of lakes to seek his fortune as a ‚ÄúTin Can Tourist,‚Äù the nickname for motorists touring the countryside at the dawn of the auto age.

In California, he stayed at an ‚Äúauto camp,‚Äù cottages furnished with a bench, table and electric light.

Chandler told Susan Poplin for a Florida State University history thesis that the two-room cabins cost $750 to build and produced a 400% annual profit.

Chandler considered himself a Horatio Alger up-from-the-bootstrap character and after a quick look around a tiny state capital city that would soon be located at the intersection of two proposed U.S. highways (27 & 90), he decided to stay and pioneer auto camping in Florida.

First, he paid $400 for some lots along the railroad tracks on Gaines Street. He built 10 cabins and a communal washroom and charged $1 a night to stay.

Two years later, he bought five acres north of town and built the Tallahassee Tourist Camp along a dirt road at Lake Ella. Once the road was paved and became U.S. 27, he expanded his camp with the Tallahassee Motor Hotel on the west side of the highway and the Lake Ella Motor Court on the east side.

The motor court consisted of 15 cottages. They were converted into apartments during a World War II housing shortage and rented for $30 a month.

Chandler used the money to upgrade the cottages with carpets, steam heat and the latest innovations. At war‚Äôs end and a tourism boom underway, Chandler promoted the Lake Ella Motor Court with hand-made billboards across the southeast.

He posted 4-by-8 feet red and yellow silkscreen painted signs advertising a motor court on the shore of Tallahassee's ‚Äúbeautiful Lake Ella,‚Äù every 10 miles on roads leading into and out of Birmingham, Atlanta, Daytona Beach, Tampa and the panhandle.

One night while out posting signs, ‚ÄúDad called home to ask about business and Mom said they were full. People told her they‚Äôd been following the signs for hundreds of miles just to stop for the night,‚Äù Gilbert Chandler Jr., told the Tallahassee Democrat‚Äôs Andy Lindstrom in 1995 for a history of the Lake Ella cottages.

After Gilbert Chandler passed, his heirs retired from the hospitality business. What had grown into the 92-room Tallahassee Motor Hotel on the west side of Monroe was torn down in the 1990s to make room for a Golden Corral restaurant.

Across the street, 11 of the original 15 cottages still stand, converted into specialty shops for the bustling Midtown neighborhood.

Their once white trim now is blue and grey, the multi-colored shingles replaced with brown ones, but they still sport marble facades. It is said, when a ton of marble was accidentally delivered to Tallahassee, Chandler bought it for a bargain to spruce up his cottages.

Chandler was a World War I veteran, Free Mason, and a Shriner who built an iconic Tallahassee destination after a disappointing first night in town.

Aquilina Howell (1917 - 2000)

Aquilina Howell was born on West Georgia Street and would go on to spend 42 years working in Leon County schools as a teacher and administrator.

What's in a name? The historic figures and educators behind Leon County school names

Howell was the first woman to serve as an Assistant Superintendent in Leon County and is credited as the driving force behind the peaceful desegregation of Tallahassee's public schools

‚ÄúAquilina had unbelievable processing skills," said former school superintendent Charles Couch who appointed her assistant superintendent. ‚ÄúShe could take angry people, get them to look at the issues calmly, and solve the problem in win-win fashion for everyone.‚Äù

Couch, and others, recall how Howell led Leon schools during desegregation without the discord and violence that plagued other communities.

‚ÄúShe could always make you calm down and see the other person‚Äôs point and make you think you did all the solving,‚Äù her sister Lucille Alexander told Gerald Ensley at Howell‚Äôs passing. ‚ÄúI used to say to her, ‚ÄòAll right, Mr. Ralph Bunche.‚Äô‚Äù (Bunche was the first Black to win the Nobel Peace Prize.)

Howell was married for 51 years to Tallahassee insurance agent Sam Howell, who passed in 1994. Howell died in 2000.

The Taylor House, where she was born, is now a museum celebrating Frenchtown and the Tallahassee Civil Rights movement.

In recognition of the path, she set a path for educators, civil activists, and community leaders, supporters created the Aquilina C. Howell Education Scholarship at Florida A&M University for first- and second-year students who graduated from a Leon County high school.

And Howell‚Äôs name can still be spotted around town; including the Leon County schools administrative building on West Pensacola Street, and the Carter-Howell-Strong Park in Frenchtown.

Carrie Meek (1926 - 2021)

Carrie Meek, the grandchild of a slave and a sharecropper‚Äôs daughter as a child, was not allowed to enter the Florida State Capitol because she was Black.

As a 12-year-old Girl Scout, Meek was blocked at the front door when white members of her Girl Scout Troop delivered home-made brownies to Florida lawmakers. As a Lincoln High School and Florida A&M University graduate, she would be the first Black woman to represent Florida in the U.S. Congress since Reconstruction.

Willie and Carrie Pittman‚Äôs daughter broke many racial, gender, and educational barriers.

In a 1992 interview with the Washington Post, she recalled in Jim Crow Tallahassee there weren‚Äôt any decent recreational facilities for Black people, and because she was Black, she couldn‚Äôt try on shoes in stores or pursue a master‚Äôs degree in her hometown.

Meek earned a Master of Science at the University of Michigan after being awarded a B.S. in biology at FAMU in 1948, and after a career as a South Florida educator she would win a 1979 special election to represent Miami in the Florida House.

In 1982, she became the first Black woman elected to the Florida Senate.

As a politician, Meek was an unapologetic Democrat firebrand with an agenda rooted in the inequities she lived and witnessed.

She is remembered as an advocate for minorities, immigrants, and the working poor. And as someone who routinely intensified the debate.

In Tallahassee when Meek wanted to kill a bill, she would stand on the floor and wave a black flag of death adorned with a skull and crossbones.

In 1994, Meek provoked a massive argument with new Republican House Speaker Newt Gingrich. She chided Gingrich for negotiating a multi-million-dollar book deal with a publishing company that had a stake in telecommunications legislation.

Meek said Gingrich stood ‚Äúto make a whole lot of dust‚Äù from the deal.

Republicans struck Meek‚Äôs comments from the Congressional Record. The argument that followed dominated the coverage of the New York Times, Washington Post, and the television news networks.

‚ÄúThe only thing missing up here is my black flag,‚Äù Meek told the Miami Herald at the time.

Carrie Meek never lost an election. She retired from politics in 2002.

The Carrie Meek ‚Äì James N. Eaton, Sr. Southeastern Regional Black Archives Research Center and Museum in Tallahassee, Florida, on the campus of Florida A&M University, is co-named in Meek's honor.

Henry Livingston Rutgers (1810 - 1861)

In 1836, Henry Livingston Rutgers, direct kin of the namesake of Rutgers University, the State University of New Jersey, married Jane Barnwall and the two moved to Tallahassee.

Florida Territorial Gov. William P. Duval had appointed Henry the Territorial Administrator and Treasurer.

Rutgers would go on to serve the territory and city for more than two decades. And although he was an early and apparently prominent settler, little is written about him.

In 1845, Rutgers cast a vote as an elector for the first Florida State Governor, William Dunn Moseley.

Rutgers also served two terms on the Tallahassee City Council and Circuit Court Judge Jesse J. Finely appointed him as an investigator in the renowned Croom-Smith Case of 1857 ‚Äì which decided ownership of Goodwood Plantation‚Äôs 200 enslaved workers.

In 1856, the Floridian and Journal newspaper, according to the Tallahassee Heritage Foundation, reported the opening of a new state bank on Monroe Street, to which the paper added, "We are indebted to Mr. H. L. Rutgers."

The Foundation suggests that druggist B. C. Lewis, who opened his own bank that year had bought the building from Rutgers.

Rutgers hired freedman George Proctor to build him two homes in Tallahassee ‚Äì the Randall-Lewis House at 424 North Calhoun St., and the Rutgers House across Calhoun and now the Tallahassee Garden Center.

It was in a cabin on Rutgers‚Äô Calhoun St property where Antonio Proctor, the scout and interpreter for the Simmons/Williams expedition that selected the site for Florida‚Äôs capital city, would pass in 1855.

Fredrich R. Cotten (1819 - 1878)

Fredrich R. Cotten had big plans for Florida when he came to Tallahassee in 1845. He got himself elected to the first Florida House of Representatives and then he developed a vast section of land that is today upper-middle class neighborhoods in north, northwest Tallahassee into the second largest cotton plantation in Leon County.

Sixty years later his grandson, Fred Cotten Elliot, would have even bigger land use plans.

He would try to drain the Everglades.

By 1850, Virginian Fredrich R. Cotten had transformed a wide swath of what is now north Tallahassee and west Leon County into a $12 million ‚Äì in today's money ‚Äì cotton growing operation.

That land today is a collection of upper middle class subdivisions, a country club, and Lake Jackson boat landings.

Cotten‚Äôs Burgesstown Plantation took in more than 8,000 acres from the Ochlocknee River and Lake Iamonia south to the Luna Pines neighborhood, east through Phipps-Overstreet Park and the eastern shore of Lake Jackson to Miller's Landing, then north to Golden Eagle Plantation, and Killearn Lakes Plantation.

Accounting records indicate that shipments of cotton went regularly from Burgesstown via St. Marks to New York with proceeds credited to Cotten.

The Leon County Florida 1860 Agricultural Census shows Cotten was the single largest slaveholder in the county, with 275 enslaved workers.

When Cotten passed in 1878, he was buried at Saint John's Episcopal Church Cemetery.

Cotten's heirs would sell Burgesstown to Lloyd Griscom of Philadelphia who in 1901 converted the land into a quail hunting plantation. Griscom‚Äôs son, Lloyd Carpenter Griscom, would purchase the Tallahassee Democrat in 1929 and the family would own the paper until 1965.

Cotten's grandson Fred Cotten Elliot became the state's chief civil engineer at the Internal Improvement Fund, now the Department of Environmental Protection. In 1913, Elliot developed a plan and directed an effort to drain the Everglades to create farmland.

Elliot joined a team of eight that hack through sawgrass to clear a path for barges, and he designed the first giant swamp buggies that allowed construction crews and farm workers to operate in the marshes of the Everglades.

When he got back home after his Everglades adventure, Elliot laid out the first few holes of the Capital City Country Club golf course.

The state-owned Elliot Building, on the SE corner of Pensacola and Monroe, across from the Capitol was named for him. It is scheduled to be demolished and the site will become a Memorial Park, whose purpose is to honor Florida history and commemorate victims of slavery and the Holocaust.

Jayleen Woods (1934 - 2006)

In 1972, Jayleen Woods was included in a Tallahassee Democrat story about women who had ‚Äúinvaded‚Äù ‚Äúmen only‚Äù professions like public relations managers, commonly referred to as "spokesmen" by the media.

Woods was a wordsmith. She was a writer and editor for the Florida Flambeau, Tallahassee Democrat and Tampa Tribune. Woods also worked 17 years as the Director of Information Services at Florida State University, where she served as the university‚Äôs spokesperson, and later as the editor of the Florida Hotel and Motel Association magazine for 30 years.

Woods said she had ‚Äúprinter‚Äôs ink in her veins.‚Äù

She got a big infusion of it after a poem she wrote as a 12-year-old, about a volunteer group called The Red Feathers, appeared on the front page of her hometown newspaper in Bristol, CT.

Five years later, she accepted a writing scholarship to Florida State University, where she would become a member of the Flying High Circus and edit the student newspaper the Florida Flambeau.

After graduating from FSU, Woods took a job with the Tampa Tribune and then met Tom Woods of Tallahassee. That would lead to a move back to the Capital City and Woods breaking glass ceilings as she moved into management positions that previously were a male domain.

Tom and Jayleen were married for 48 years and had two daughters. He preceded her in death.

In retirement, Jayleen created fund-raising brochures for the Girl Scout Council and its Apalachee Camp for All Seasons. She also remained active with the League of Women Voters, Springtime Tallahassee, the Women‚Äôs Club of Tallahassee, and the Seminole Boosters.

Thomas DeSaille Tucker (1844 - 1903)

A native of British Sierra Leon, Thomas DeSaille Tucker was a lawyer and missionary who became the first president of the State Normal College for Colored Students, which became Florida A&M University.

He was a graduate of Oberlin College in Ohio and taught at schools for emancipated slaves in Kentucky and Louisiana, before opening a law office in Pensacola.

Tucker devoted his life to combatting slavery, according to a Oberlin College biography.

"The colored men in this country have no voice in the general government; even in some of the States they have no voice in the State government," he wrote to a friend in Africa. "It would fairly sicken you to be here on a fourth of July and hear guns firing and 'starspangled banner' waving 'over the land of the free and the home of the brave' while there are this day 4,000,000 of slaves in their possession. O what a hypocrisy. God will not always sleep but will yet come in judgment against this country except they speedily repent."

In 1887, Tucker accepted appointment as the first president of the State Normal College for Colored Students in DeFuniak Springs. With an infusion of federal money, Tucker moved the school to Tallahassee onto property once owned by Gov. Willliam Duval.

When the State Board of Education selected Tucker to be the school‚Äôs first president, the editor of a local newspaper wrote:

‚ÄúWe have known Professor Tucker for about 18 years and we have never met a more genial, broadminded and sterling gentleman. He possesses first-class qualities as a friend, gentleman and scholar, and commands the respect of all who know him. He is a strong man, morally and intellectually, and the new Normal has a security of success under his charge.‚Äù

Tucker served as president until an argument with William N. Sheats over the school‚Äôs direction. Sheats wanted Tucker to focus on agricultural and industrial education, Tucker insisted on a liberal arts education.

Sheats was appointed Superintendent in 1895 and slowly reduced Tucker‚Äôs authority and reduced the school‚Äôs budget and questioned spending until Tucker was finally ousted in 1901.

Tucker moved to Jacksonville where he practiced law until his death in 1903.

The Sims; Robert (1924 - 1966), Helen (1932 - 1966), Joy (1954 - 1966)

Three members of the Sims family are the victims in a story that local lore holds as the moment Tallahassee lost its innocence.

October 22, 1966, was a football Saturday and that night 30,000 people, more than half of the city‚Äôs population, attended the Mississippi State University vs. Florida State University football game at Doak Campbell Stadium.

Robert Sims, the director of data processing for the Department of Education, Helen Sims, a former secretary for First Baptist Church, and their 12-year-old daughter Joy did not.

Vicious killers invaded their home in a quiet, upper middle-class neighborhood and the three were found bound, gagged and shot shortly before 11 p.m.

Robert and Joy passed at the scene. Helen was rushed to the hospital and never regained consciousness to provide any clues to the killers. She died nine days later.

Sixteen-year-old ambulance attendant Rocky Bevis was among the first responders to the crime scene. He cut the bonds on all three victims at their ankles and wrists.

"We just woke up one morning in Tallahassee and we were part of an evil world,‚Äù he recalled to the Miami Herald for a story marking the 50th anniversary of the crime.

Before that October night, Tallahassee was a place where people did not lock their doors.

But as word of the murders spread, homes started to be kept locked at all hours, doors not opened to strangers, shades were drawn at dusk. And when no arrests were made, people bought watchdogs, hardware stores ran out of locks and safety door chains, and there was a rush at gun shops.

Fear spread through the city to the extent that Trick or Treat was cancelled that Halloween.

A Tallahassee Democrat editorial stated, ‚ÄúThis is no night to send young children in masks and costumes into the street.‚Äù

A $16,000 reward was never collected. The murder weapons were never found. A motive never established.

Sheriff deputies had two suspects in their sights, and nearly 1,000 fingerprints collected at the scene but never secured enough evidence to bring any charges.

The late Leon County Sheriff Larry Campbell investigated the murders as a deputy and continued to probe the case through a 53-year law enforcement career.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve done everything I think I can do,‚Äù he told the Miami Herald in 2006. ‚ÄúThe big frustration is that I feel very confident that I know who did it.‚Äù

The case remains unsolved. Campbell passed in 2014.

Ed Ball (1888 - 1981)

From the dark days of the depression and until his death in 1981, Ed Ball was one of the most powerful and feared men in Florida.

Ball owned a 7,500-acre farm outside of Tallahassee that today is the Southwood subdivision.

The brother-in-law of Alfred I. du Pont, Ed Ball managed du Pont‚Äôs finances and once Alfred died grew a $56-million du Pont trust into a $2-billion Florida empire, according to the Wall Street firm A.G. Becker.

A du Pont grandson filed suit against Ball for spending too much money to make more money instead of on the charitable organizations the elder du Pont included as the trust‚Äôs beneficiaries.

Among the trust‚Äôs holdings were more than 1 million acres of north Florida timberland, the St. Joe Paper Company, Florida East Coast Railway, Apalachicola Northern Railroad Co., Florida National Bank, Talisman Sugar Corp, Florida Sugar Refinery Inc., and St. Joseph Telephone and Telegraph.
